loans.name: Toatolu

texts.en: Toatolu is 71 years old and has 9 children. Her talent is making elei (traditional Samoan fabrics). She has turned her talent into a business to meet her family's needs.  Some of her children help her craft the elei from Monday to Friday. They then deliver the goods to shops and flea markets in Savalalo. Toatolu earns $130 WST ($52 USD) daily. She is looking forward to her second loan so that she can expand the business and rebuild her house.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her elei printing business

loans.name: Aperila

texts.en: Aperila is 36 years of age. She is married with three children. She is strong and doing well.  She started her business by selling brooms and coconuts and has expanded her range of goods to handicrafts and clothes.  Aperila earns $250 WST ($100 USD) in profit after all expenses a week. Apart from her income, her husband is working and earns extra money for their family needs.  Aperila is now on her 6th loan. She would like to use this loan to expand her business and renovate her family's house.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her handicrafts business

loans.name: Faaleo

texts.en: Faaleo is a 64 year old mother from the village of Puipaa. She has a second-hand refrigerator, which prompted her to begin an ice cake business with the help of SPBD loans. Her husband does not work and there is no other source of income for her to support her family and children. Faaleo plans to use this loan to buy materials to make the ice cakes. She is looking forward to selling her goods at school and also to the village people. She will work six days of the week and she is looking to earn $100 WST ($40 USD) or more a week.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her bakery

loans.name: Fofoga

texts.en:
Running a fast-food stall for two years now has allowed this member to pay off all her loan and has improved her business. Fofoga A. is one of our very good clients who have shown so much effort in the programme, and she is still going strong. At 29, she is still very young to be in such a demanding business. She has two children and her husband is helping her a lot with the fast-food stall. It is the main source of income for their family.

Fofoga earns about $90 WST (US$ 36) daily and her business is up and running six days a week. She use her income on family expenses, for example, church, household bills, food, and also of course to pay back what she owes SPBD on her loans.

loans.use: To buy chicken, turkey, taro, curry, flour, soy sauce, and other ingredients for her fast-food stall

loans.name: Ester

texts.es:
Mrs. M. lives in her own home in the Las Delicias neighborhood of Lourdes. She has sold clothing for more than 30 years. Her elderly husband cannot work or earn very much so the money Mrs. M. makes must support both of them. In order to increase her income, she is asking for a loan to buy more merchandise ahead of this busy shopping season. She is very entrepreneurial and hard-working and has been a client in good standing of Integral for a year and a half and has repaid her previous loans punctually.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. M. ,vive actualmente en colonia las Delicias de El salvador, la casa es propia , tiene 30 años de dedicarse a este negocio la venta de ropa, su fuente de ingresos dependen directamente de este negocio, ya que su esposo no genera mucho dinero, por la edad que tiene , y prácticamente ella tiene que cubrir los gastos del hogar , el crédito lo esta solicitando para poder ampliar mas su negocio y poder incrementar mas sus ventas en esta temporada del año y así poder generar los ingresos necesarios para salir adelante es cliente vigente de Integral desde hace año y medio y en todos sus créditos a mostrado puntualidad en sus pagos es una persona emprendedora y trabajadora..

loans.use: To buy bedspreads, children's and women's clothing.

location.town: Col. las Delicias Pasaje 2#69 Lourdes, Colon

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es:
Mrs. Z. lives with her husband and children in their own home in Lourdes, Colon. She has a small shop in the home where she sells groceries, drinks and candy. With the income this generates she's is able to help with the household expenses. She will use this loan to stock the store with the products customers have requested but which she didn't have the funds to buy.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Z. actualmente vive en casa propia en Lourdes, Colon ,la señora tiene una tienda, en su vivienda, en la cual vende productos de consumo y golosinas ,su aporte con el negocio le sirve para poder cubrir parte de los gastos familiares y así poder ayudar a su esposo a sacar adelante a su hijos su propósito con el crédito es comprar algunos productos que los clientes buscan pero que por falta de dinero no a podido comprar, con este crédito surtiría sus estantes y así podrá prestar un mejor servicio a sus clientes.

loans.use: To stock a small grocery store.

loans.name: Seneuefa

texts.en:
Seneuefa is married with 4 kids and lives in a family of 9 people. She is 38 years of age and is from the village of Vailele. After her school years, she stayed home and looked after her family. She found the SPBD programme and she wanted to take a small loan from us to start her elei print business. She’s the right age to do elei (a traditional Samoan fabric) printing and she has the skills and experience for printing the materials in different designs.

Seneuefa estimates that she earns around $240 WST (US$ 96) a week from her business. They have not only the elei printing as a source of income, but her family also has a banana and taro farm, and they earn about $150 WST (US$ 60) a week selling 2 or more sacks of taro in the market.

loans.use: To buy materials and supplies for her handicrafts business

loans.name: Faalagilagi

texts.en:
Faalagilagi is 21 years old and married. She has been helping run her family farm for a long time now, and this is the only source of income she has. She is the one who sells the stuff at the market but her brother and her father are the ones who work on the farm.

Faalagilagi sells the produce at the market three times per week and makes a profit of about $200 WST (US$ 80) per day. She appreciates the help she gets from our program and she hopes to stay in it for a long time.

loans.use: To buy tools and chemicals for her little farm

loans.name: Mele

texts.en:
Mele is a mother from Puipaa Center. She is thirty-one years of age and she is running a small farm and an ice cake (popsicle in a bag) business. She has three children who are still young. Her husband works as a carpenter and that was her only source of income for the family before she joined our programme.

Mele sells her ice cakes for fifty cents each at the Primary School Compound, but she sells the produce from her farm at the Fugalei Market. She is one of our really hard-working ladies and she is reliable and supportive.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her ice cake (popsicle) business

loans.name: Luaono

texts.en: Luaono is the president of Moamoa k Uta Center. She has been running her shop for more than three years now and this is the first time she is borrowing money for the business. Luaono's shop is located at the front of her house. It is open from six o’clock in the morning till nine in the evening. The shop is actually owned by her daughter but when the daughter moved to New Zealand, Luaono took over. She keeps her shop open six days a week and she can manage to earn about $340 WST (US$ 136) a day. Luaono is still active and she is doing well at running her business.

loans.use: To restock her shop

loans.name: Faititili

texts.en: Faititili is a mother of seven, aged fifty-four, currently running a bingo business, together with her little farm. Faititli belongs to a group of 19 members, left with only eleven active members. This lady has helped her group in paying off their inactive members' loans. She has good income from her business that has improved her family in many ways. Faititili is requesting this loan in order to buy fencing for her fields and purchase prizes for her bingo games as well.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her bingo business and her small farm

loans.name: Toetu

texts.en: Toetu F. is a single lady of twenty-four who wants to start a small vegetable garden business. Toetu has joined a group of eleven women with seven active members, three inactive ones, and one who just passed away two weeks ago. Toetu has also attended three weeks' training and has successfully passed her exam that allows her to borrow from SPBD. Toetu aims to get her businessup and running and wishes, down the road, to extend it with her business profit.

loans.use: To buy seeds for her vegetable garden

loans.name: Faafetai

texts.en: Faafetai is a single twenty-six-year-old lady. She’s a new member to our program who wants to start a small elei (a traditional Samoan fabric) printing business but has no job and couldn’t borrow money anywhere for financial support to start her business. Faafetai then decided to join SPBD which is the only micro-finance company that can help her make her dream come true. She has attended three weeks' training with the program and is now requesting her first loan. She hopes that her business will turn out to be successful so that she can support her parents and the whole family.

loans.use: To start up an elei (block printing on cloth) business

loans.name: Ruth Noemi

texts.es:
Mrs. C. has built and now runs a small grocery store in the neighborhood of Las Moritas.  Beginning with very little she has slowly built the business up by reinvesting her profits.  The location is a busy one and Mrs. C. believes that with a little more investment in the goods her customers desire, the shop will succeed.   Translated by a Kiva volunteer.  
La Sra. C. posee una  tienda que a construido con esfuerzos propios ,en la colonia las Moritas .
Según comenta ella  inicio su negocio con poco pero a podido ir incrementando su negocio ,con lo poco que le queda  D. ganancia, el negocio esta ubicado en un lugar muy transitado por lo cual eso le genero la inquietud D. querer invertir mas y a si poder ofrecer otros productos que los clientes buscan.

loans.use: To stock a small grocery store with such things as soft drinks and grains.

location.town: Col. Las Moritas Calle 17 de Mayo pasaje H #16 Lou

loans.name: Matauaina

texts.en: Matauaina M. is an old member of ours who joined SPBD three years ago. She has paid off her last loan and is now requesting this loan in order to buy more young taro plants to grow in her small farm. Matauaina is really excited and is still interested in staying in the program because she is now holding cash that she never did before. But with a good mind, she is saving up some of her income for "a rainy day", because she believes that not all days are good, and so it’s good to save now, so that when bad days come, she will be well prepared. She plans to extend her little farm and start looking for new markets.

loans.use: To buy a lawn mower and agricultural chemicals for her small farm

loans.name: Lauifi

texts.en: Lauifi is a widow aged 65 with 8 children. She’s a relatively new member to our program who has paid off her first loan with no difficulties. She used her first loan to start her BBQ business and it's running well. Lauifi feels happy with the income she’s earning. With her second loan, she will buy more food for her BBQ and pay her grandchildren’s school fees.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her BBQ, and to pay her grand-children’s school fees

loans.name: Lefaima Ah

texts.en:
Lefaima is a seventy-five-year-old widow with sixteen children, and she comes from the village of Afega. She was one of SPBD’s first clients when we started our program in the year 2000. She has had eight loans through SPBD and has fully paid back all of them without difficulties.

Lefaima is a very active woman and is willing to stay in the program for as long as she lives. The financial support that SPBD have provided has helped her in many ways, which she is thankful for. She says that without this support she would never be where she is right now. With her requested loan, she plans to buy a bigger freezer for the ice cakes (popsicles in a bag) which she sells.

loans.use: To buy a new freezer for her popsicle business

loans.name: Rosa Ah

texts.en: Rosa is the mother of 8 children and is thirty-nine. Her husband is unemployed but does fishing  to help support their family. Rosa's business is making popcorn and ice cakes (popsicles in a bag) that she supplies to their village primary school. Rosa enjoys doing her business every day because she relies on its income to support her family. With her requested loan she plans to purchase more ingredients to increase her daily production of snack foods.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for her snack-food business

loans.name: Lorraine

texts.en:
Running a canteen for over 5 years has allowed this member to pay off all her loans in a timely manner. She has also been able to improve her business with those loans. She is among our very good clients who have put so much effort into our program and she is still going strong. She’s a 37-year-old lady who has no children and got divorced from her husband one year after their marriage.

Lorraine explains that she is planning to turn her canteen into a restaurant when she is ready to do so. So with her requested loan, she will buy more stock for her business.

loans.use: To restock her canteen (small shop)

loans.name: Talani

texts.en: Talani is a hard-working woman of 40 years of age. She puts in hard labor on the farm that supports her family. She has five children. She repays her debt well and is always trying to better her small business. She is an upstanding client and an asset to the local economy.

loans.use: To buy a lawn mower and pesticides for her small farm

loans.name: Norma Rosibel

texts.es:
Norma has a small business selling groceries out of her home. She has two children and shares the home with her partner. Part of her business is selling groceries on credit to neighbors who settle their accounts either biweekly or monthly. Several of these customers have accounts outstanding but Norma has to restock her store so she is asking for a loan herself. This will really help her improve her income to meet the expense of raising two children. It will also make available to her customers the groceries they seek.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

La Sra se dedica a la comercialización D. alimentos D. consumo diario, este negocio lo tiene en su casa D. habitación , su grupo familiar lo componen dos personas sus hijos y su compañero D. vida. Ella trabaja con algunos clientes con cuentas por cobrar, solicita su financiamiento para poder surtir y comprar algunos productos que se a quedado sin ellos y que son D. demanda en el sector ,esto le ayudaría en gran manera para poder mejorar sus ingresos y a la misma vez poder ayudar a su esposo con los gastos D. manutención D. los hijos también contribuiría en gran manera para poder darle a sus clientes productos que buscan y que por no tenerlos tienen que recurrir a otros negocios D. la localidad.

loans.use: To stock a small grocery store.

location.town: Col.Las Moritas Calle 17 de marzo lote#11 Lourdes

payments.comment: This entrepreneur has prepaid the balance on her loan. She is very grateful for your loan and appreciates your support.

loans.name: Utuloa

texts.en: Utuloa is the mother of 5 children. She is a hard-working woman who has been putting a lot of effort into our program. She is always trying to improve her small business. With previous loans she was able to manage the hard problems better and to increase the farm's productivity and profitability. With this requested loan, she plans to buy pesticides for her farm.

loans.use: To buy pesticides for her small farm

loans.name: Soli

texts.en: Soli is a 55-year-old lady who is has raised eight children, presently ranging in age from 17 to 31. She previously owned and operated a successful home improvement company & is now looking after their farm business. She has had an immaculate account history and continues to repay current debts in full and on time.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her small farm and her fishing business

loans.name: Faye

texts.en: Faye L. is a mother of three, aged thirty-four, from the village of Lalovaea. She is the secretary for their community, acting as a role model for the other ladies. She had an immaculate account history with her first loan and will continue to repay current debt in full and on time. Faye is requesting a loan for the second time now and she will use it to buy more handicrafts for her business, for it is the Christmas season and more tourists will visit Samoa and will take home souvenirs.

loans.use: To buy handicrafts to sell at her flea market stall

loans.name: Kilisitina

texts.en: Kilisitina is a relatively new member of our program, and she fully paid off her first loan in just four weeks! Before joining SPBD, she already had an existing business, a flea market stall, but didn’t have enough items to sell. She borrowed from SPBD and used it to buy good quality handicrafts which she said are all sold out now. She is requesting another loan to buy more handicrafts for her market stall. This lady also has a good savings account which she is preserving "for a rainy day".

loans.use: To buy handicrafts to sell at her flea market stall

loans.name: Taufua

texts.en: Taufua is a twenty-six year old mother of three children who runs both a small farm and a fishing business. Her husband works for Yazaki EDS Company and is not earning enough to support his family. Taufua is very happy to be in our program to have financial assistance to keep her business growing, so she can help out her husband with taking care of their family financially. She aims to keep both businesses growing to earn good income to provide her children with a better education than she and her husband got.

loans.use: To buy pesticides for her little farm and new fishing nets

loans.name: Koreti

texts.en:
Koreti R., aged twenty-seven and the mother of two children, runs an ice cake (popsicle in a bag) and a fishing business. She has fully paid off her previous loans which she used to improve both businesses. Her husband is unemployed and helps out Koreti with the businesses.

The fishing business has helped Koreti in many ways: she has been able to send her kids to school and put food on the table for the whole family. She aims to save up and buy a fishing boat in the future, for she’s sure that her family is better-off because of the business.

loans.use: To buy new fishing gear

loans.name: Claudia Janet

texts.es:
Mrs. R.'s clothing shop is favorably located on one of the main streets of Lourdes. She sells men's and women's clothing. A very entrepreneurial woman, she started her business with very little but has built it up steadily such that it now serves to support her family. At this time she needs to invest in more merchandise.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. R. tiene su negocio en una de las calles mas principales de Lourdes ,ella vende pantalones para caballero y damas y ropa de todos los estilos, necesita invertir mas por la temporada y algo que le favorece es tener una buena ubicación en el negocio es muy propicio para que se vendan los productos en los cuales quiere invertir ,la señora es muy emprendedora , su negocio lo inicio con poco y hasta la fecha lo a ido incrementado paulatinamente, de este negocio obtiene los fondos necesarios para poder mantener a su familia, ya que dependen directamente de ese ingreso que obtiene de las ventas .

loans.use: Buying t shirts, trousers and underwear to sell at the Lourdes market.

location.town: 3ra Calle poniente casa numero 3 lourdes Colon , l

loans.name: Blanca Estela

texts.es:
Blanca lives in the Lourdes neighborhood and runs a beauty parlor there.  In addition, she sells hair care products and cosmetics to the customers who come see her to round out her income.  She counts on these activities to support herself and her family .  This loan will enable her to buy products cheaper in bulk and free her from the irregular service of her current suppliers and thus provide better service to her customers.  This loan will generate more income for her family.    Translated by Alexis Hult, Kiva volunteer.  



Actualmente la solicitante vive en una colonia de Lourdes, tiene una sala de belleza y al mismo tiempo , tiene una venta de artículos de belleza y cosméticos los cuales le generan un ingreso extra, aparte del servicio que presta ,  vende  productos de belleza a los  clientes que la visitan, la solicitante depende directamente de esta actividad y al invertir con el préstamo que se le daría ella podría prestar un mejor servicio y no depender de los proveedores que le llevan el producto, ya que es  mas caro y no con la frecuencia con ella lo necesita  y además generaría mas ingresos para su familia.

loans.use: To buy beauty products, hair coloring and conditioner.

location.town: Residencial Los Choros Senda Cuatro casa numero 3

loans.name: Rosa

texts.pt:
Rosa A. is married and mother of 8 children. She is in the business of selling cow heads, which she does from home and at a street stand in Trevo-Matola, Mozambique. She joined the credit program in 2006 and has paid previous loans timely. Rosa plans to use this, her 5th loan to date, to increase her stock of cow heads.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer.

Rosa A. portadora de BI nº 110002315P, casada de 8 filhos vive no bairro trevo é negociante vende cabeças de vaca na sua propria residencia entrou no projecto no ano de 2006 tomando 1800 agora esta no 5º ciclo vai tomar o valor de 20000 mt para pagar em 8 meses tambem faz o negocio ambulante.

loans.use: stock increase

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To boost her telephone and grocery business

loans.name: Aora Yoro Tek Women Group

texts.en:
Teresa A. M. is an average Kenyan woman aged 38 and married with 2 children. She also lives with the 2 orphan children of her late sister. Teresa started her second-hand clothing business 4 years ago after retiring from her teaching profession which she had done for over 10 years.

Teresa deals in ladies and children’s wear. She purchases her bales of clothes every Sunday from Kibuye market which is well-known for its wholesale clothing business. With the little profit that she gets from her business, Teresa is still able to clothe, feed, and educate her children and relatives with the help of her husband who works as a technician in Kisumu town.

With the help of her loan, Teresa would like to diversify her business and bring in more men’s wear, and she would also like to capitalize on the January school season and bring in school uniforms to boost her sales. 
Teresa’s long-term business vision is to expand her business into a boutique, and she would also like to open up a nursery school in the future.

loans.use: Purchase more bales of clothes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase her clothes business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase tables, chairs, and umbrellas

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase her farming business

loans.name: Sareth

texts.en:
Mrs. K. Sareth, 41, and her husband, Kuch Von, have been married since 1990. Their four children, ages 6-17, are all attending local schools. Sareth and her husband have had a business of buying and reselling flowers and bananas for the past 27 years. Once a week, they drive 10 km to purchase their goods from local farmers before making the journey into Phnom Penh to resell at the large markets there. They currently sell seven varieties of flowers and two of banana. Von also farms tobacco and raises pigs to help support the family.

Sareth is requesting her third loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $1,200. She will use this loan to purchase a one-season contract at specific flower and banana farms. Previous loans were used for the same purpose. By this system, the wholesaler estimates the output per farm and bids on a contract for everything grown that season. Because of the high up-front cost, Sareth finds it difficult to save this money, which is why she is seeking another loan. These contracts for goods will provide the family with a stable income over the next many months.

loans.use: Buy flowers and bananas for reselling

loans.name: Rukhsana

texts.en: I am Rukhsana N. from Lahore, the second largest metropolis in Pakistan. I am a mother of five, all of whom attend a local school. We own a brick house here in Lahore. My husband is a scrap dealer but he also sells tea cups and glasses. He works very hard to provide for his children and send them to school. He roams about in the city on his cycle and collects objects of iron and steel against cups and glasses and at times on cash. We need a loan to further expand our business and buy cups and glasses in bulk.

loans.use: Expand business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase five bales of second-hand clothing.

loans.name: Nheb

texts.en:
Mrs. T. Nheb, 41, has been married for 23 years. Her husband works for the government is away from home much of the time. They have three children, ages 10-23, who are all still living at home. The youngest is still in school. The oldest son and daughter have finished their education and now work to help support the family. For several years, Nheb has been growing jasmine. Like many of her neighbors, she tends a small plot in the back of her home. Six years ago, Nheb stopped her business of food sales to begin working as the wholesaler for flowers in her village.

Nheb is requesting her eighth loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $800. She will use this loan to purchase a one-season contract at specific flower farms. Previous loans were used for the same purpose. By this system, the wholesaler estimates the output per farm and bids on a contract for everything grown that season. Jasmine plants do not have a significant output of buds every day so Nheb collects these small amounts from many farms to sell in bulk. Sometimes she collects 300 grams, and sometimes up to 3 kilos. The local middleman comes to her house every day to make a purchase. Because of the high up-front cost, Nheb finds it difficult to save this money, which is why she is seeking another loan. Nheb says this business has been profitable for her and she is grateful for the opportunity to borrow to continue improving her family's standard of living.

loans.use: Buy jasmine flowers

loans.name: Puthy

texts.en:
Mrs. K. Puthy, 41, and her husband, Sok Mab, have been married for 20 years. They have five children, ages 2-18, and another one on the way. So far, they have been able to provide a basic education for them all, and the oldest is now working in the local garment factory to help support the family. Mab is the primary earner in the family and has been farming for nearly 20 years. They own two hectares of land, about 10 km away from their home, where he plants rice. Now it is planting time and Mab will spend day and night in the fields working to get them prepared.    

Puthy is requesting her third loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $200. She will use this loan to purchase fertilizer and a sprayer for her husband. Previous loans were used for the same purpose. Mab explains that the cost of fertilizer is up this year from $20 USD for a 50 kilo sack to $33--a significant increase. He will be busy over the next few months as the availability of water on their land only allows for one planting a year, so he must make the most of it. They will keep some of the rice for personal use and sell the bulk to a buyer. Besides farming, the family also raises pigs to provide additional income year-round.

loans.use: Buy fertilizer and sprayer

payments.comment:
Dear lender,

Mrs. Puthy Kim has enough money to pay off her loan early before contract.

Thank you.

loans.name: Balqees

texts.en: My name is Balqees M. B.. I am married and a mother of nine: six daughters and three sons. I could not send my children to school because of our poor financial circumstances. My husband used to make kites but after the government banned the business we had to face very difficult times. Then two years ago, my husband started another business of selling spices via his bicycle by acquiring a loan from Asasah, a microfinance institution. Our business does well and we would like to have another loan to make our business even better. I plan to save the extra income for my daughters' weddings.

loans.use: Expand spices business

loans.name: Ya

texts.en:
Mrs. N. Ya, 49, has been divorced and supporting her family as a single mother for nearly 18 years. She has five children, ages 18-28, who are all grown and working to help support the family. Now, four still live at home in addition to a son-in-law and newborn child. Ya has been a farmer for over 20 years, following the fall of Khmer Rouge regime. She grows cauliflower and two kinds of squash which she rotates with corn. In the plot of land behind her home, she is able to plant two cycles per year with the water available.

Ya is requesting her third loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $600. She will use this loan to purchase vegetable seeds and a wooden cart for transporting her produce to the larger markets in Phnom Penh. Previous loans were used to purchase a water pump and motorbike. With a new cart, Ya will no longer have to hire a motor-taxi every time she wants to sell. Instead, she can connect the cart to her moto and make the trip by herself, saving time and money.

loans.use: Buy vegetable seeds and a wooden cart

loans.name: Sophun

texts.en:
Mrs. C. Sophun, 52, has been married for 15 years to her second husband.  Between the two of them they have several children, but only one still lives at home with her husband and young son. Also under their care are one granddaughter and Sophun's elderly mother. Since they are older, Sophun and her husband now mainly take care of the family and tend their fruit trees. They also raise cows. Sophun's granddaughter, 20, and daughter, 28, are two of the primary supporters now as they have secure jobs in the local garment factory.  

Sophun is requesting her third loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $500. She will use this loan, in addition to other money she has saved, to purchase supplies for improvements to their home. Previous loans were used for similar purposes and to build a cow shed. With this new loan, Sophun hopes to purchase the necessary bricks, rebar and concrete needed to further enclose the open first floor of their modest stilt home. They will also pour a concrete slab floor in place of bare earth. This new space will allow the seven family members to live together with more privacy and comfort.

loans.use: Home improvement

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James Mwangi M. is 25 years old and married with 2 children. James lives in a town called Ruai on the outskirts of Nairobi. James is a businessman. He runs a general shop which is situated at the Ruai Center. James started off as a waiter in a hotel from the year 2002-2003, but he decided to quit the job due to poor working conditions including a very low salary. In the year 2004, he started a green grocery stand with savings which he earned from his previous job. Through the profits that he earned from the grocery, he expanded his business and started selling cereals and stocking items like sugar, flour and salt.

James's business has been doing well, although he finds that he has been unable to increase his stock due to lack of finances since he has a business to run and also a family to support. As a result, his business has come to a standstill while he has been wondering where he can get money since the few banks that he tried to approach charged high interest rates that he felt he could not pay. While still wondering about this, he noted that his friend and neighbor, Mary Wamaitha, who is a beneficiary of a Kiva loan, had suddenly raised her business from nowhere, and it was growing fast. He therefore inquired how she had managed to do it so quickly, and she informed him about Kiva. He was greatly impressed. Mary went further and brought him to the ANK offices so that he could also receive support.

James is kindly requesting a loan of US$650 which he will use to stock his shop with cereals like maize, peas, beans, rice, sugar, and flour, among other items. He believes that, with this loan, he will be able to expand his business and increase the number of customers he has. This way, he will be better able to support his family. Since he is a young person, he also hopes that he will be able to expand his business up to a wholesale level over time.

The repayment period for this loan will be 9 months.

loans.use: To purchase stock for a general store, including cereals like maize, peas, beans, rice, sugar and flour etc.

loans.name: Sivorn

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Sivorn and her husband, Mr. Cheng Sarin, have been married since 1984. (They are photographed with some of their children). They have ten children; four sons and six daughters, two of which are married and live in separate houses. Four of their children are studying in the local school and the other sare helping her in doing business. Sivorn has been a farmer for over 20 years, following the fall of Khmer Rouge regime. Now she is a melon wholesaler. Sivorn started this business in the year 2002. She buys melons from farmers on contract. She pays money to farmers while they start growing melons. When harvest season comes, she collects melons for reselling at the market in Phnom Penh. Her husband is a moto-remolque (trailer) taxi driver and helping her in selling melons.

Sivorn is requesting her third loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $1000. She will use this loan to buy melons in contract from farmers in her village. Previous loans were used to do similar business.

loans.use: Buys Melon in contract from the farmers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his milk business

loans.name: Chamroeun

texts.en:
Mr. P. Chamroeun and his wife have been married since1987. They have four children; two sons and two daughters. One of the sons builds wooden houses with him and one of his daughters is working in a garment factory. Chamroeun and his family live along National Road number One about twenty five kilometers from Phnom Penh. He started his business in the year 1985. His wife stays at home and takes care of their children.  

Chamroeun is requesting his first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $500.  He will use this loan, in addition to other money he has saved, to purchase supplies for finishing his wooden house (shown in photo).

loans.use: Home building

loans.name: Sokhum

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Sokhum and her husband have been married since 1980. They have five children; three sons and two daughters. Two of Sokhum’s children have been married and live in a different house. One of her daughters is working in a garment factory. Sokhum has one brother living under her custody and who works at a company in Phnom Penh. Sokhum and her family live along National Road number Six about thirty kilometers from Phnom Penh. She is selling Num Krouk (one kind of Cambodian food--see photo) in front of her house. Her husband is doing construction work in the village and does farming.

Sokhum is requesting her third loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $1000.  She will use this loan to purchase a motorbike for her brother traveling to work in Phnom Penh.

loans.use: Buy a motorbike for transport

loans.name: Sabari

texts.en: I am a mother of five: four boys and one girl. I live with my family in a brick house in Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. I need a loan of  $350 for my husband‘s blankets and rugs business. He buys these items from Peshawar, a city in north of Pakistan that is famous for its cheap items and Faisalabad, a city famous for its textiles in Pakistan. He then sells these products on his bicycle in nearby villages and here in Lahore. With your loan he will buy blankets in a high quantity for this busy season.

loans.use: Buy blankets in a high quantity

loans.name: Hoe

texts.en:
Mrs. M. Hoe is a widow with four children--two sons and two daughters. Two of her children have been married and live in a different house and other two children live under her custody and do fishing in the Mekong River. Her family lives along National Road number Six about thirty kilometers from Phnom Penh. Currently, she is in the business of selling secondhand cloth in the market at her village. She started her selling in 1992. Hoe and her children have never attended school. 

She is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $350.  She will use this loan to purchase a boat and a boat motor for her children to do fishing.

loans.use: Buying a boat and a boat motor for fishing

loans.name: Elnur

texts.en: Elnur was born in 1980, is single, and lives in the Salyan region, in the village of Yenikand. Four years ago he started his farming business. Now he is requesting a loan of $475 to buy fertilizer and pesticides to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Rukia

texts.en:
Rukia M. is married with two children, Kulutuiui, 11, and Hashim, 5. At just 29, Rukia is an experienced businesswoman. Between 1999 and 2003 she opened three businesses: one selling charcoal, one selling fish, and a shop/stall selling groceries. Rukia has already repaid two loans from SELFINA and now requires another to expand her first business, charcoal. These small, black and dirty pieces of dry earth are important not just to Sarah but to her customers who rely on charcoal to cook their meals. Many Tanzanians still use small coal pots, in which they arrange mkaa (charcoal) and add either paper, dry grass, old plastic bags or kerosene in order to light them. The fire requires constant fanning to ignite and maintain the flame and makes cooking quite a hot and laborious task. It may not be the easiest or most environmentally friendly form of cooking, but it is the only option many people can afford. Which is good news for Rukia, who requires a loan of $1075 in order to add to her stock of mkaa and continue meeting customer demand.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation for women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of charcoal for re-sale

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Skirts and sandals, halters and heels. As you can see, Fatuma Mbagau has a classy range of clothes and shoes. She established her clothing business in 2004 and expanded it to include shoes in 2006. Now Fatuma requires a loan of $200 to purchase additional stock, which she hopes will help her to increase her monthly profits of approximately $80.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation for women.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To extend her range of clothes and shoes for re-sale

loans.name: Thi Vinh

texts.vi:
Ms. Vinh is 45 years old. She is living with her family in Cho town, Yen Phong, Bac Ninh. She is a very dynamic woman. At first, her family overcame the difficulties and earned some money for her children to go to school by working for other stores. They saved money and opened an Internet cafe. Currently, their income is from the Internet cafe. Through the fund, she would like to borrow money to expand her business.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Vinh đã 45 tuổi, chị sống cùng gia đình tại phố Chờ, Yên Phong, Bắc Ninh. Chị là một người phụ nữ rất năng động. ban đầu, gia đình chi cũng vất vả khó khăn mới kiếm được ít tiền nuôi con ăn học bằng cách làm thuê cho các cửa hàng. Về sau, hai anh chị cũng dành dụm và đã mở được một quán Internet. Bây giờ, anh chị có nguồn thu nhập từ việc kinh doanh internet. Qua chương trình, chị muốn vay một khoản tiền để mở rộng cửa hàng.

loans.use: Expand her Internet cafe

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To improve his milk business

loans.name: Tulambe

texts.en:
This is 39 year-old Tulambe K.. Earlier this year she established a business raising and selling chickens to supplement her monthly salary of $70 from the Tanzanian Prisons Service where she is employed. Tulambe is requesting a loan of $275, with which she plans to purchase additional chicks. The business helps Tulambe to support her two children, Theresia, 17, and Eva, 12.

loans.use: To purchase additional chickens to raise and sell

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
This is 23-year-old Mama Hythan (that name comes from her 4-year-old son who's named Hythan). In 2005 she opened a grocery store (randomly called Dar Pub), where she sells a range of food items; butter, biscuits, rice, oil etc. Mama Hythan requires a loan of $900 to expand this business by purchasing additional stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

loans.name: Mwanahamisi

texts.en:
This is 39-year-old Mrs. Mwanahamisi C.. If that name is too difficult, it may be easier to use her nickname, Mama Pana (in reference to her third-born child; I hope the others aren’t jealous!) Mama Pana runs a business selling clothes, specializing particularly in kangas (long kaftan-like dresses made from colourful African cloth.) She established the business in 2005 and requires a loan of $1075 to purchase additional stock.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation for women.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of clothing.

loans.name: Gadir

texts.en: Gadir lives in the Salyan region, in the village of Yenikand. He was born in 1983, and has 3 years of experience in his business. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to purchase baling presses.

loans.use: To buy baling presses

loans.name: Bouré Réffé Toukkel Group

texts.fr:
The group is a micro-enterprise from the ecovillage of Palmarin and is requesting a loan for business activities. Their aim is to fight poverty and combat the exodus and covert immigration of young people by helping them have access to goods locally through the setting up of a store selling fishing supplies and other general items. 

 Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer.



Le groupement est un GIE de l'éco villave de palmarin qui sollicite un prêt pour des activités économique.
Afin de lutter contre la pauvreté, l'exode et l'immigration clandestine des jeunes en les aidant de par nos activités de pouvoir se dotter de matériel sur place en implantant un magasin de vente de divers matériel de pêche et autres.

loans.use: To buy and sell general goods

loans.name: Nuru

texts.en:
This is 30 year-old Nuru M.. She runs a ‘duka’ (shop) in the rural town of Pangani, where she sells a variety of foodstuffs, such as rice, oil, sugar, biscuits, butter, and candy. Nuru established the business in 2005 and has already repaid one loan from SELFINA. She now requires a loan of $625 to purchase additional stock in bulk. Nuru is married to husband Seifu and has four children under 16.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation for women.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her general store

loans.name: Gumru

texts.en: Gumru (her mother is pictured) has her own farming business. She started this business 5 years ago. She was born in 1981, is single, and lives in the Salyan region, in the village of Khaladj. Now she needs a loan of $1200 to buy fertilizer to improve her farming business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Osteria

texts.en:
Vegetarians avert your eyes! This is Osteria M. and she runs a butcher’s shop in the rural town of Mlandizi, about 30km outside of Dar es Salaam. In Swahili, a butcher business is called ‘kuchinja ngombe”, which literally translated means ‘the slaughter or ruthless killing of animals’. Ruthless killing? Maybe I’ve just managed to change the minds of a few meat-eaters!

Osteria established the business in 2006 and requires a loan of $375 to purchase additional equipment and stock. She is married to husband Leonadi with whom she has three children, Grace, 14, Ronado, 9, and Devota, 2.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation for women.

loans.use: To purchase additional equipment and stock for her butcher's shop

loans.name: Dafroza

texts.en:
This is 33-year-old Dafroza M.. She is married to husband Frank and has two little girls, Glory, 5, and Grace, 2, who are just as pretty as their names suggest! In 2006 Dafroza established a business selling African batik cloth. She requires a loan of $375 to purchase additional stock.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation for women.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of African batik cloth for her business

loans.name: Oishahon

texts.en:
Oishahon is a creative person who has one cherished wish: to purchase a car for her husband.

When she heard about the KIVA program she said that it is Christmas wonder, because she had saved money to purchase a car and hoped to do this the night before New Year for her lovely husband, as he has always supported her in their family life and in her business.

But in the beginning of September her eldest child needed an operation and she spent the biggest part of her saved money on him. Now he is getting better and Oishahon and her husband work hard to make the best holiday for their children.

Yesterday she came to the MicroInvest office and asked to take part in KIVA's program with the purpose of increasing her assets to make a big purchase of new perfumes. She said that it will help her to get max profit and she can purchase a car for her husband. P.S. In the photo you can see Oishahon with her husband.

loans.use: Oishahon would like to increase the volume of her goods before the New Year so she can purchase a car for her husband.

loans.name: Thi Nga

texts.vi:
Mrs.Nga is born in 1961. Her two children are still going to school. Everyday, she goes to the market to sell knives and scissors. Her husband stays at home and sells metal. Their lives are so harsh because they are so dependent on the income from the sales. Therefore, she wants to borrow a small amount of money to buy more stuff to sell so that she can earn more money for her family. She feels that she is capable of paying back the loan on a weekly basis.

Translated from Vietnamese by Duy Hua, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Nga sinh năm 1961, chị có hai người con đều đang đi học. Hàng ngày, chị vẫn đi chợ bán dao kéo.Chồng chị ở nhà bán sắt. Cuộc sống của hai vợ chồng chị thật khó khăn khi trông vào nguồn thu nhập từ bán hàng. Chị muốn vay thêm một khoản tiền nhỏ để mua thêm hàng bán tạo thu nhập cho gia đình. Chị thấy khả năng hoàn trả vốn theo tuần rất phù hợp với chị.

loans.use: Buy knives and scissors to resell.

loans.name: Amana

texts.en:
This is 45-year-old Amana M.. She runs a kiosk where she sells bits and pieces and odds and ends (candy, cigarettes, phone credit, etc.). Amana established the business in 2004 and now requires a loan of $550 to purchase additional stock. She is married to husband Maonaje and has four grown-up children.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of small items for re-sale

loans.name: Akif

texts.en: Akif (his son is pictured) is married and has 2 children. This man was born in 1963, and he lives with his family in the Salyan region, in the village of Khaladj. Ten years ago he started his business to support his family. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy foodstuffs, and therefore increase his income.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs

loans.name: Hija

texts.en:
It is said that Coca Cola® (I don’t want to get kiva.org sued) is one of the most recognized symbols or ‘words’ in the world. And it’s true. Even in the most remote villages in Africa, there is usually some kind of ‘bar’ selling Coke, Fanta, and Guiness (personally, I think Guiness should be added to the ‘most-recognised’ list). Pepsi has made it to most African capitals but not to the sticks (get your act together guys; this is the age of multinational rule, so it’s now or never!)

Hija Kone is one of many Tanzanians in the soda business, and she operates her business in the rural town of Tumbi, approximately 30km north of Dar es Salaam (it’s hard to say if Tumbi fits into the Pepsi-selling category or not). Hija is requesting a loan of $375 in order to purchase additional stock in bulk and expand her business.She is married to husband Neto and has two children, Akialhi, 7, and Paulo, 4.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation for women.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of soft drinks for re-sale

loans.name: Manzuma

texts.en:
Manzuma I. has been engaged in trade for over 7 years. Her business is located in Panjshanbe market, Khujand, Tajikisatan, in the passage of the market, as you can see in the photo. She says that her business trade is profitable and she does not want to change her location. While doing her business she has attracted many constant clients and her place is convenient for them as it is located near the transport road. Every day she sells the majority of her goods. She goes to Istaravshan wholesale market weekly to purchase more goods.

To the KIVA program she has directed an urgent request of a loan to increase the volume of her goods. She recently married her daughter off and she currently needs additional capital to stabilize her working capital. And in the nearest future she wants to make a wedding present - she wants to give furniture to her daughter.

loans.use: Manzuma would like to Increase the volume of goods for her children's clothing store.

loans.name: Jameela

texts.en: I am Jameela B.. I am married and a mother of five: four girls and one boy. One of my daughters and son is preparing for grade ten exams, whereas the others are small and attend junior classes. My son, along with preparing for his exams, also runs a mobile phone shop with one of his friends on a partnership basis. He is able to earn $100 monthly from his business. Now he plans to expand his business further for which we request from you a loan of $350.

loans.use: To expand mobile phone store

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina M. is one of Tanzania’s strong-necked and strong-spirited women who walks from place to place selling various items from a huge basin, basket, or box balanced perfectly on her head. The ‘machinga’s” (hawker’s) job is not an easy one but often the only one available. Amina requires a loan of $725 to purchase additional stock. She is married to husband Msabaha and has four children between the ages of 15 and 22 years.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation for women.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional items to sell.

loans.name: Thi Tam

texts.vi:
Ms Tâm is 39 years old. She is married and has 2 children. Everyday she makes "chè" (a typical vietnamese sweet dessert/snack which is made of mainly coconut cream, tapioca bubble & beans ..yummy) and sells it in front of her house. Her husband held all kind of jobs but now he's home helping her running the "chè" stand. This is their main family income. They wish to borrow 2.006.000VND (~125 USD) to stock up the ingredients. They will set aside savings to repay the loan.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Tâm năm nay 39 tuổi, chị đã lập gia đình và có hai đứa con. Hàng ngày, chị vẫn nấu chè và bán tại nhà. Chồng chị trước đây cũng làm nhiều nghề nhưng bây giờ anh ở nhà phụ chị bán hàng. Nguồn thu nhập chính của gia đình chị từ việc bán chè. Anh, chị muốn vay với số tiền 2.006.000VND mua thêm nguyên liệu để nấu chè. Lãi từ việc thu nhập này anh, chị sẽ trích một phần hoàn vốn và đóng tiền học cho con.

loans.use: Buy ingredients to make dessert ("chè")

loans.name: Zaina

texts.en:
When you walk down the streets of Dar, you are greeted at almost every corner by a stall or wheelbarrow full of mangoes, pineapples, bananas, or sugarcane. It is possible that some of this luscious fruit is produced by Zaina R., who established a fruit-growing business in 1999. She now requires a loan of $725 to expand production. Zaina is married to husband Christopher and has three children.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation for women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. loans.use: To expand production at her fruit farm

loans.name: Sajida

texts.en: I need a loan of $350 for my husband’s vegetable business. He sells his vegetables on his donkey cart in nearby areas and makes a profit of $10 a day. We have a daughter and she is one year old; we wish to send her to the best school in town in future. Earlier, we took a loan for the same business and made our profits better. I share my husband’s financial burden by making bangles on contract for $1 a day.

loans.use: Expand vegetables business

loans.name: Hyasintha

texts.en:
Hyasintha L. sells pots and pans, spatulas and spoons, in fact almost everything except the kitchen sink. She established her housewares business in 2005 and now requires a loan of $900 to purchase additional stock. She is married to husband Bahata who works at a primary school. Hyasintha is a teacher at a high school. She and Bahata have a baby daughter, Faith, who is three months old.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation for women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her housewares shop

loans.name: Zainabu

texts.en:
This is 49 year-old Zainabu Luhoza. She runs a business selling gently used clothing in the rural town of Tangini, about 30km outside Dar es Salaam. She requires a loan of $900 to purchase additional stock, which she hopes will help her to increase her modest monthly profit of about $50. Zainabu is a widow and has two children, Kidawa, 15, and Zaima, 17. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation for women.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of used clothing for sale

loans.name: Razia

texts.en: My name is Razia L. and I am from Lahore, a big metropolis in Pakistan. I am married and a mother of four sons and three daughters. My husband and one of my sons sell henna and hair oils to make a living. They have been in this business for more than ten years. These days it is a high season because of Eid (a Muslim religious festival) and weddings so the demand for henna has risen sharply. We need to expand our business so that we can earn better profits, which I plan to save to collect dowries for my daughters.

loans.use: Expand current business

loans.name: Marselina

texts.en:
Mama Ahunga established a ‘duka’ (shop) in 2006, which carries a vast array of stock, made up of both food and non-food items. Miscellaneous is probably the best description. She has already successfully repaid two loans from SELFINA and now requires a third to purchase additional stock in bulk. She is married to husband Elisha, with whom she has four children aged between 12 and 20 years.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation for women.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk for her general store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her milk business

loans.name: Elimeness

texts.en:
This is Elimeness T., commonly known as Mama Joshua (in reference to her 1-year-old son, Joshua). In 2005 she established a business selling both Western clothing and African batik clothing. Mama Joshua now needs a loan of $450 to expand her colourful and interesting range. The business enables her to assist her husband Alpha to support their son, as well as Alpha’s daughter, Evelini, 12.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation for women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of Western and African clothing for re-sale

loans.name: Arshad

texts.en: I am a mother of five children: four daughters and one son. Three of my daughters are married and my son sells blankets and rugs, whereas my husband operates a fruit cart. We could not educate our children because of our poor financial circumstances. But now, due to my son’s income, times have changed and things are much better. My son managed to start his business with the loans we acquired from Asasah, a microfinance institution.  We need another loan for our blankets business to improve our income further.

loans.use: Improve blanket business

loans.name: The Queen Group

texts.en: They call themselves "The Queen," and the group includes (left to right) Mary S., Eda M., Prukeria K. and Stella M.. They are residents of the Buza area in Dar Es Salaam city. Mary and Eda own beauty salons, and the rest own small restaurants, businesses they have been doing for the past five years. Ever since they received business and entrepreneurship skills training, they have realized the importance of teaming up and doing business and bargaining together. They are each in need of USD 400 to help them expand their businesses.

loans.use: To expand their business

loans.name: Ulkar

texts.en: Ulkar is a mother of 4 children. She lives with her family in the Salyan region, in Khaladj village. She was born in 1957. She has been in the farming business for 10 years. Now she needs a loan of $1200 to buy fertilizer to improve her farming business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Zawadi

texts.en:
Beautiful and well-groomed, 25-year-old Zawadi is a good advertisement for her business. She runs a hair and beauty salon in the town of Kibaha, approximately 25 km outside of Dar es Salaam, where she cuts, curls, dyes, plaits, plucks, and files. Zawadi requires a loan of $450 to purchase additional stocks of hair and body products and continue beautifying her clients. She is married to husband Samatha and has one child, Sabrina, who is 4 years old.

loans.use: To purchase beauty and haircare products to use at her salon

loans.name: Khursheed

texts.en: My name is Khursheed B.. I live with my husband and eight children in Lahore, a great city in the Indo/Pak history. My husband is a property dealer and one of my sons manufactures audio tapes with various spare parts and sells them to various factories. My son needs a loan to buy required spare parts in bulk. We need to increase our income so that we can construct a few more rooms in our house.

loans.use: Buy spare parts for the business in bulk

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha G. began selling clothes in 1999, and in 2001 she expanded her business by adding shoes, curtains, and bedclothes. Her business currently generates an average profit of approximately $80 per month. Aisha hopes to increase her profits by purchasing additional stock in bulk, for which she requires a loan of $275. Aisha is married to husband Jumanne, with whom she has two children, Shaban, 19, and Mariam, 12.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation for women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of clothing, shoes, curtains, and bedclothes

loans.name: Vailet

texts.en:
In 2002 Vailet M. opened a small shop selling basic groceries. Five years later, having wisely invested and repaid two loans from SELFINA, Vailet has expanded the business so that it now generates a monthly profit of around $550, which is a considerable amount in Tanzania. Vailet now wants to expand her business further, by increasing the quantity and range of her stock and buying in bulk. She is married to husband Patson and has five children between the ages of 5 and 18 years.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation for women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client extending a loan to her and then leases back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her general store

loans.name: Irshad

texts.en: I am Irshad B. and wife of Shabbir Ahmed from Lahore. I have six children: four boys and two girls. All of my children completed their studies up to tenth grade only and all are married except the youngest. My husband works at a paper factory for meager income and I sell cloth. I travel to Faisalabad (a city famous for its textiles in Pakistan) and buy cloth from there and sell it here in Lahore. I have been in this business for the past two years and make decent profits. I need a loan to expand my business further and buy cloth in bulk.

loans.use: Buy cloth in bulk for the business

loans.name: Vagif

texts.en: Vagif has been in this business for 7 years. He breeds sheep. This man is 55 years old,  married, and has 5 children. The S. family lives in the Salyan region in the Yenikand village. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy baling presses (for hay) that he needs to improve his sheep breeding.

loans.use: To buy baling presses

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her retail shop

loans.name: Yasmeen

texts.en: My name is Yasmeen A.. I was married four years ago and live with my family in Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan. I am a member of my loan group for the past two years and have already acquired two loans for my husband’s business of selling blankets and rugs. He sells these items on his bicycle by roaming about in various parts of the city. With the profits, by investing loans earlier, I bought a TV and a washing machine for myself. Now we need a loan to expand our business. I will save the extra profits from this expansion for my husband’s sister marriage and will buy her a few beautiful expensive gifts.

loans.use: Expand blanket business

loans.name: Jenifer

texts.en:
This is 28 year-old Jenifer N.. She runs a pharmacy in the rural town of Kiluvya, about 30km outside of Dar es Salaam. She established the business in 2005 and now requires a loan of $725 to purchase additional stock. She is married to husband Edward and has two children, Ester, 7, and Samwel, 1. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are deemed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, and then leases back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To increase her pharmacy's inventory of drugs

loans.name: Mukhtaran

texts.en: My name is Mukhtaran B.. I am married and a mother of nine: five sons and four daughters. All of my sons and their father sell blankets and rugs on contract. Now they want to buy a stock of these items for themselves so that they can increase their income. We need to increase our income so that we can collect a dowry for our daughters and construct an additional room in our house.

loans.use: Buy blankets in bulk for the winter season

loans.name: Vusal

texts.en: Vusal A. is a single man who lives in the Salyan region, in Yenikand village. This young man has 5 years of experience in in the farming business. He was born in 1984. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy fertilizer.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Naziran

texts.en: My name is Naziran B.. I am married and a mother of six: four boys and two girls. I need a loan of $300 for my husband’s blanket business. He has been in this business since his teens. He sells these items door to door on his bicycle. I could not send my children to school earlier, but now I feel it is never too late so I have decided to enroll them in school again. With your loan my husband will buy blankets and rugs in bulk

loans.use: Buy rugs, runners, and blankets in bulk

loans.name: Sabra

texts.en:
I need a loan of $350 for my husband’s woolen items business that includes blankets, rugs, and bed sheets. He is able to make a profit of $100 a month out of this business. Previously, we took out loans and invested in our business and hence managed to raise our income which enabled us to marry one of our sons. 
I am a mother of five: two sons and three daughters and live with my family in Lahore, a city with great history and traditions in Pakistan.

loans.use: Buy blankets for the winter season in bulk

loans.name: Rehana

texts.en: I am Rehana K.. I was married 17 years ago and I am a mother of two kids: one boy and one girl. My daughter has completed her fifth grade and my son attends a local school. I need a loan of $175 for my husband’s blanket and runner business. He has been in this business since his teens and it is our family business. It is winter season here presently and the demand for blankets is very high. We therefore need to expand our business and buy blankets in bulk. I will save the extra profits from this expansion to make gold earrings for my daughter.

loans.use: Buy blankets in bulk

loans.name: Safarali

texts.ru:
S. Safarali is 47 years old, has higher technological education and an electrician by profession. He is married and has 3 children. Safarali's main work place is in the Yavan city power station where he works as an electrician. Besides his job he is also raising cattle at his home. He will use the loan to purchase 3 heads of cattle to raise and sell them. He will use the profit to buy more of young cattle and the remaining money to support his family because his very limited salary is not enough and he does not have any other means of income. Safarali is planning to pay off the loan in 15 months.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Сафаров Сафарали, возраст – 47 лет, образование высшее техническое, по специальности – электрик, женат, имеет 3-х детей. Основным местом работы Сафарали является Городские электричесикие сети города Явана, где он работает электриком. Помимо этого он также занимается разведением крупного рогатого скота у себя дома. На полученный кредит клиент планирует приобрести 3 голов крупного рогатого скота для их откормки и перепродажи. Вырученные деньги он будет использовать на приобретение молодняка, а оставшуюся прибыль будет направлять на содержание своей семьи, так как небольшой размер заработной платы не хватает на месяц. Других источников дохода он не имеет. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 15 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase 3 heads of cattle to raise and sell

loans.name: Shakila

texts.en: I am Shakila M.. I live in Lahore, the second largest city in Pakistan with my husband and five kids: one son and four daughters. My husband paints buildings and furniture on order. He needs to buy few items for his business such as paints and brushes for which we require a loan of $175.

loans.use: Buy paints and paint brushes, etc.

loans.name: Rustamjon

texts.ru:
Rustamjon Sattarov, who is 25, is a graduate of a specialized college and possesses a certificate in the area of sales. His business is located in the central market in the city of Kurgan-Tube. The main products that Rustamjon sells are shoes for men, women, and children. He has been in this business for the past 5 years. Using the loan, he plans to purchase additional sets of shoes for men, women, and children. This loan will help residents of Kurgan-Tube and other surrounding areas purchase needed shoes within the city. That way they will not have to leave for the city of Dushanbe, which is located 60 miles away. Rustamjon plans to pay off the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova. Kiva Volunteer.

Сатторов Рустамджон, возраст – 25 лет, образование среднее, окончил торговый техникум по специальности продавец. Рустамджон занимается торговлей на центральном рынке города Курган-Тюбе. Основным товаром, которым он торгует является обувь для мужчин, женщин и детей. Этим видом деятельности он заниается уже в течение 5 лет. На полученный кредит он планирует приобрести новый ассортимент мужской, женской и детской обуви. Этот кредит поможет жителям города Курган-Тюбе и близлежащхих районов приобретать необходимую женскую обувь у себя в городе, не выезжая для этого в город Душанбе, находящийся на расстояние 100 км от Кургран-Тюбе. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of new inventory for winter season

loans.name: Afrika Group

texts.en: The Afrika group is made up of four hardworking ladies, from left to right: Mariam R., Zuhura S., Mariam M. and Rehema A.. They are all residents of the Tandiika community, a Dar es Salaam city suburb. They all run small restaurants in Tandiika municipal market, which they have been doing for the past five years. They are each in need of USD 400 to help them expand their businesses.

loans.use: Expand their businesses

loans.name: Bibigul

texts.ru:
Bibigul U., who is 41, is married and has 2 children. Bibigul specializes in sales of traditional Tajik clothing. For this business, she rents a space on the market "Rurkat and Panchshanbe" in the town of Yavan. Using the loan, she plans to increase the assortment of her inventory. This will give local residents an better choice in the offered clothing so they will not have to go to the other closest market located in the city of Dushanbe, 50 miles away. Bibigul plans to pay off the loan in 10 months.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova. Kiva Volunteer.

Уракова Бибигул, возраст – 41 год, образование среднее, замужем, имеет 2-х детей. Бибигул занимается торговлей национальной одеждой. Для этого она арендует торговую точку на рынке «Руркат» и «Панчшанбе» города Явана. На полученный кредит она планирует увеличить ассортимент продаваемого товара, что даст возможность жителям Яванского района иметь большой выбор среди предлагаемой одежды и не ездить за нужным товаром на близлежащий рынок, который находится на расстояние 80 км, в городе Душанбе, что окажет влияние на экономию их временных и денежных ресурсов.. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 10 месяцев.

loans.use: To inrease the assortment of inventory

loans.name: Hikmat

texts.en: This single man was born in 1980. He lives in Salyan region, in the Khaladj village. He has been in  the farming business for 7 years. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy fertilizer and pesticides.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Yuldosh

texts.ru:
Yuldosh E., who is 59, is married ans has 6 children. He has been in the business of breeding and selling cattle for 10 years. Using the loan, Yuldosh plans to purchase 2 cows and forage. After feeding the cattle for 40 to 45 days, he plans to sell it and use the profits to repeat the original purchase. Extra money will be used for the needs of the family. Yuldosh plans to pay off the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova. Kiva Volunteer.

Эгамбердиев Юлдош, возраст – 59 лет, образование среднее, женат, имеет 6-х детей. Юлдош на полученный кредит планирует приобрести 2 головы крупного рогатого скота и корма для них. После их откормки через каждые 40-45 днец он планирует их продавать, а на вырученный деньги приобретать новый молодняк и корм, оставшуюся прибыль использовать на удовлетворение потребностей семьи. Этим видом деятельности он занимается уже в течение 10 лет. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of 2 cows for future resale

loans.name: Banda B9B Group

texts.en: She expects to increase on her income, expand more than her level now.  She also thinks she can various entities of bussinesses in various locations.

loans.use: to open a retail shop

loans.name: Tagoygul

texts.ru:
Tagoygul S., who is 53, is married and has 6 children. Tagoygul takes care of the house and the animals. Using the loan, she plans to purchase 2 cows that can be fed over time and resold later on. She plans to hold the cattle for 40 to 45 days before she sells it. Because she spends all her time at home, she will use this activity as a source of income that will enable her to become independent and to purchase things necessary for maintenance of her family. Her son helps her in the sales of cattle.

Tagoygul plans to pay off the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Vasilisa Budnikova. Kiva Volunteer.

Шарипова Тагойгул, возраст – 53 года, образование среднее, замужем, имеет 6-х детей. Тагойгул домохозяйка, она занимается домашним хозяйством. На полученный кредит она планирует приобрести 2 головы крупного рогатого скота для их откормки и продажи. Так как целыми днями она находится дома, приобретя домашний скот она будет ухаживать за ним и после откормки, через 40-45 дней будет продавать его, что позволит ей получать небольшую прибыль, которая поможет Тагойгул быть независимой, а также приобретать необходимые вещи на деньги заработанные собственным трудом. В продаже скота ей помогает ее сын. Клиент планирует выплатить кредит в течение 12 месяцев.

loans.use: Purchase of 2 cows for future resale

loans.name: Banda B9 Group

texts.en:
Joyce M. hopes that the loan that she is requesting will enable her to build and enhance her quality of life. With the loan, Joyce expects her tailoring business to grow bigger than it is currently is. Therefore the loan will increase the capital in her business.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: Bigger tailoring store
