texts.en: With this, her second loan, Maria hopes to support her small farm business. She makes good money from her farm and therefore it is a must for her to keep it going. It is the only source of income for her and she needs to sustain it otherwise she will not have any more money for her use and to support her family.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her small farm and for home improvement

loans.name: Vaasa Oloitoa

texts.en: Vaasa owns a taxi and the assistance from SPBD goes to the maintenance of the taxi. She has said that the taxi makes good money and therefore she needs to ensure that it is in good condition all the time. It is quite expensive to maintain the taxi and so she needs the extra help from SPBD to be able to do that.

loans.use: To provide maintenance for her taxi service

loans.name: Lanuola

texts.en: Lanuola is not new to the SPBD programme and her business is a plantation and she fishes in addition to that. She would like to buy some new tools for her business and that is what she would use the funds for. She said she is happy with SPBD’s help and will welcome the opportunity for another loan in future.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation and for home improvement

loans.name: Faisealofa

texts.en: Faisealofa is an SPBD client who joined this programme when she wanted to start a small business. Even though it is only selling pop corn, it has made a start for her as a business woman. She married a man from Mulifanua and that’s when she started her business. She also receives a remittance from her aunty overseas and other members of her extended family. That was her financial support before she joined SPBD for extra assistance. Now she manages to support her family and send her kids to school with this simple business.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her popcorn business and also for home improvement

loans.name: Tafagamanu

texts.en: Tafagamanu is a hard-working woman of 40 years of age. She does hard labour on the farm that supports her family. She has five children. She repays her debt well and is always trying to improve her small business. She is an upstanding client and she could be an asset to the local economy.

loans.use: To buy a lawnmower and pesticides

loans.name: Rosana

texts.en: Rosana is a new member to the programme who wants to start a small ice cake (popsicles in a bag) business. She is a mother of 2 sons, she is unemployed and stays home looking after her children. Rosana feels happy that she has financial support for her husband who fishes all day and then walks at night in the village trying to sell fish. Her requested loan will help her start her ice cake business.

loans.use: To start her ice cake business

loans.name: Lucia

texts.es:
Lucia is a member of the community bank La Amistad in the district and province of Moyabamba, in the department (region) of San Martín. She works selling groceries in her house, which is located on Jaen Street in the Vista Alegre neighborhood of the city of Moyabamba. She started her business with a credit from the community bank and went along growing her business, little by little. She started with a table on which she displayed a few products. The business has grown thanks to her effort and the good service she provides to her clients. Lucia decided to start the business despite not being able to count on the support of her husband because she is a very hard working person with good business skills. What's more, generating her own income nourishes her self esteem and allows her to contribute to the expenses of helping her children get ahead.

This loan of 1800 soles (Peruvian currency), which she'll repay in 4 months, will buy groceries such as rice, sacks of sugar, boxes of milk of many different sizes and brands, boxes of oil, packages of detergents, boxes of noodles, onions, sacks of garlic, and other products to better stock her business. She wants her clients to find what they are looking for when they come to her store; her sales are stronger when she offers a variety of merchandise. She takes advantage of the fact that she has no competition in her neighborhood.

Lucia is 37 years old with 3 children. She now has her husband's help in the business, as well. Lucia is happy with what she does and satisfied by the resuilts she has achieved up to now. Her clientele has grown, which also has helped her improve her economic situation and contribute to covering the family 's expenses. Her goal is to one day have a kiosk across from her house. A grade school is currently under construction there, and she wants to be prepared when it opens for classes so that she can increase her business by selling refreshments.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Lucia es socia del banco comunal La Amistad del distrito y provincia de Moyabamba, departamento de San Martín. Se dedica a la venta de abarrotes en su casa que está ubicada en el Jr. Jaen S/N del sector Vista Alegre de la ciudad de Moyabamba. Se inició con el crédito del banco comunal y poco a poco fue creciendo. Se inició en una mesa con algunos productos. En la actualidad el negocio ha ido creciendo gracias a su empeño y la buena atención que les brinda a sus clientes. Decidió iniciar el negocio a pesar de no contar con el apoyo de su esposo porque ella es una persona muy trabajadora y hábil para el negocio, además genera sus propios ingresos, alimenta su autoestima y le permite apoyar con los gastos que requiere para sacar adelante a sus hijos.

El préstamo de S/. 1 800.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará abarrotes como arroz, azúcar en sacos, cajas de leche de diferentes marcas y tamaños, aceite en cajas, paquetes de detergentes, fideos en cajas, cebolla , ajos en sacos, y otros productos para surtir mejor su negocio porque quiere que sus clientes encuentren lo que buscan, cuando hay variedad aumentan las ventas. Ella aprovecha que no tiene competencia en su barrio.

Tiene 37 años y 3 hijos, ahora cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo, está contenta con lo que hace y satisfecha por los resultados obtenidos hasta la fecha, su clientela aumentó, eso también ayudó a que mejore su situación económica y apoye en los gastos familiares. Su meta es contar con un kiosco al frente de su casa, porque al frente se está terminando de construir un instituto y quiere estar preparada para cuando inicien las clases para ampliar su negocio con la venta de refrigerios.

loans.use: Buy groceries as inventory: rice, sugar, milk, oil, etc.

loans.name: Maria Exilda

texts.es:
María Exilda is a member of the community bank La Amistad and lives in the suburb Las Orquídeas in the district and province of Moyabama and the department (region) of San Martín. Exilda started her business by selling live chickens but she saw that it wasn't very profitable . She then succeeded in acquiring a stall in the Moyabamba central market where she sells all sorts of eviscerated birds, such as free range chickens, ducks, and sometimes, turkeys. Thanks to her perseverance and good service, her sales have grown well. She serves restaurants in the city, clients she knows, and she also delivers to her clients' homes. She decided to start her own business because she enjoys her work, plus it allows her to generate her own income, which in turn has strengthened her self esteem and allowed her to grow as a person and a woman.

With this loan of 1000 soles (Peruvian currency), which she will repay in 4 months, Exilda will buy more chickens and ducks, since the holidays are approaching. During the holidays, she sees increased demand for her meats from institutions hosting end of year dinners and her restaurant clients, who also see increased business at this time of year.

María Exilda is 46 years old with 6 children. She lives with her husband and her youngest daughter, who helps her in the business and the household activities. She is happy to be able to count on the support of her husband and daughter. Her goal is to own a restaurant and create jobs for other people.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Maria Exilda pertenece del Banco comunal La Amistad, vive en la Urb. Las Orquídeas del distrito y provincia de Moyabamba, departamento de San Martín. Exilda se inició en el negocio con la venta de gallinas vivas pero vio que no era muy rentable y logró conseguir un puesto en el mercado central de Moyabamba donde vende todo tipo de aves eviscerados como gallina de corral, pato y algunas veces pavo. Gracias a su perseverancia y buen trato sus ventas aumentaron. Atiende a restaurantes de la ciudad y personas que ella conoce y reparte a domicilio. Decidió iniciar un negocio porque es algo que disfruta haciéndolo, además le gusta estar en contacto con la gente y ello le permite generar sus propios ingresos, lo cual aumenta su autoestima y le permite crecer como persona y mujer.

El préstamo de S/. 1 000.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará más gallinas, pavos, porque ya se acercan las fiestas de fin de año y es donde hay mucha demanda de esta carne cuando las instituciones realizan sus cenas de fin de año y también aumenta el requerimiento de los restaurantes a quienes atiende.

La señora Maria Exilda tiene 46 años y 6 hijos, vive con su esposo y su ultima hija, quien la apoya en el negocio y las actividades de la casa. Está contenta porque cuenta con el apoyo de su esposo e hija. Su meta es llegar a tener un negocio familiar. que es un restaurante y poder dar trabajo a M. personas.

loans.use: Buy chickens and ducks

loans.name: Julia's Group

texts.es:
Julia is 35 years old and has 2 children. Maria Carmen is 32 years old with 2 children, and Victoria is 31 years old and has 4 children. They are all part of the communal bank called Sol Radiante (radiant sun). They told us that they began their businesses with a savings of just a few dollars, and that the members of the bank are a close, united group, demonstrated by the fact that if somebody has a problem, everybody helps out.

Julia makes beautiful woven handicrafts, a skill she inherited from her parents. 20 years ago she began to make the pieces on her own, together with her husband and children. She creates individual pieces and sends them to Cusco to sell. In addition, she has a small general store in her house. Victoria also works with woven handicrafts. She learned from her husband who has been doing this since he was young. Like Julia, Victoria makes individual pieces and sends them to Cusco.

Maria Carmen, on the other hand, has a shop where she sells general groceries and speciality items. She sells her things from a space she rents close to the market of Santa Clara. She brings her products from Lima, and sells them wholesale. She used to also work in handicrafts, like her friends, but she left it to begin her business which was more profitable. She began her new work 6 years ago, selling door to door and around the markets, little by little growing the business.

Julia, Maria Carmen and Victoria will use their savings for their children's education, and to improve their homes. They will invest the money in cinnamon, mushrooms, cloves, noodles, milk, rice, sugar and sodas, as well as wool, dyes and threads. All of these woman have a dream that their children will receive a good education and become professionals, that their businesses continue to grow, and that they will have happy family lives.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

Julia tiene 35 años y 2 hijos, Maria Carmen tiene 32 años y 2 hijos, mientras que Victoria tiene 31 años y 4 hijos. Ellas pertenecen al Banco Comunal Sol Radiante desde hace 13, 13 y 5 años respectivamente. Julia y Maria son fundadoras del Banco Comunal Sol Radiante, y nos cuentan que iniciaron con un ahorro de 2 dólares y que las socias en su banco son unidas y solidarias, lo cual se demuestra cuando las socias tienen algún problema y todas las socias se apoyan.

Julia hace lindos trabajos de Artesanía en Telar, arte que fue heredado de sus padres. Hace 20 años realiza los telares independientemente junto a su esposo e hijos. Ella elabora individuales y los envía a Cuzco, además tiene una tienda de abarrotes en su casa.

Igualmente Victoria realiza trabajos en telar, actividad que aprendió de su esposo que es artesano desde pequeño. Victoria, al igual que Julia solo hace individuales y también los envía a Cuzco.

Por otro lado Maria Carmen es comerciante y tiene una tienda de abarrotes y especerías. Ella vende en un local alquilado cerca al Mercado Santa Clara, y sus productos los trae desde Lima y vende al por mayor. Maria Carmen también fue artesana al igual que sus compañeras, pero dejó esta actividad por el comercio, que nos dice era más rentable. Se inició en este negocio hace 6 años como ambulante y poco a poco fue creciendo.

Julia, Maria Carmen y Victoria utilizarán sus ahorros para los estudios de sus hijos y para la mejora de su casa.

Ellas necesitan préstamos de 1000 soles, 800 soles y 800 soles respectivamente que serán invertidos en la compra de canela, hongos, laurel, achiote, comino, clavo de olor, fideo, leche, arroz, azúcar, gaseosas, lanas, tintes, hilos.

Los sueños de Julia, Maria Carmen y Victoria son que sus hijos sean profesionales, que su negocio crezca, vivir feliz junto a su pareja e hijos, y exportar sus telares.

loans.use: To invest in their respective businesses, purchasing  cinnamon, mushrooms, cloves, noodles, milk, rice, sugar and sodas, as well as wool, dyes and threads.

loans.name: Zenaida's Group

texts.es:
Zenaida, Elizabeth, and DomitiL. have belonged to the Sol Radiante (Radiant Sun) communal bank for 8, 10, and 12 years respectively. In this time, they have learned to be punctual and responsible, to save, and above all, to work and support their families.

Zenaida is 45 years old and has four children. She travels to markets in Manallasacc and Sachabamba where she buys cheeses, grains, and meats to later sell in the city of Ayacucho. She also travels to the jungle Ayacuchana carrying these goods.

Elizabeth is 38 years old and has three children – and three businesses. Fifteen years ago she began by selling cosmetics, but after joining the communal bank, she began a beauty salon. Later, she began to sell clothing on order.

Meanwhile, DomitiL. creates fine weavings, a skill she learned when she worked with her brother 14 years ago. Little by little, she become more independent, and now she has her own shop and works with her children; they create landscapes in tapestry and sell them in the Santa Clara market in Ayacucho.

Their loans are for 800 soles, 400 soles, and 1400 soles which they will invest in the purchase of cheese, beans, corn, quinoa, meat, polos, sweaters, pants, blouses, cosmetics, wool and dyes. They will use their savings for their children’s educations, emergency funds, to take trips with their children, and to expand their businesses. Zenaida’s, Elizabeth’s, and DomitiL.’s dream is that their children will become professionals, they can improve their homes, buy land, own successful and larger businesses, and run a clothing store.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

Zenaida, Elizabeth y DomitiL. pertenecen al Banco Comunal Sol Radiante desD. hace 8, 10 y 12 años respectivamente. En todo este tiempo ellas dice que aprendieron a ser puntuales, a ser responsables, a ahorrar y sobre todo a trabajar y mantener a su familia. Zenaida tiene 45 años y tiene 4 hijos. ElL. viaja a las ferias D. Manallasacc y Sachabamba donD. compra quesos, cereales y carnero para luego venderlo en L. ciudad D. Ayacucho. Asimismo, viaja a L. selva Ayacuchana llevando estos productos. Por otro lado Elizabeth tiene 38 años y 3 hijos, elL. tiene 3 negocios. Se inició hace 15 años con L. venta D. Cosméticos, pero después D. entrar a su Banco Comunal elL. implementó su salón D. belleza y posteriormente comenzó a vender ropa a pedido. Mientras que DomitiL. realiza bellos trabajos en telar, actividad que aprendió cuando trabajaba con su hermano, hace 14 años. Poco a poco fue independizándose, ahora tiene su propio taller y trabaja con sus hijos; hacen trabajos D. tapices, caminos y los venD. en el mercado Santa Clara D. Ayacucho. Sus préstamos son D. 800 soles, 400 soles y 1400 soles que los invertirán en L. compra D. queso, haba, maíz, fréjol, quinua, carneros, polo, chompas, pantalones, camisas, cosméticos, lanas, tintes. Sus ahorros los utilizarán para L. educación D. sus hijos, alguna emergencia, para salir D. vacaciones con sus hijos y para aumentar el negocio. Los sueños D. Zenaida, Elizabeth y DomitiL. son que sus hijos sean profesionales, mejorar L. construcción D. su casa, comprar un terreno, ser una empresaria D. éxito, tener un negocio más granD. y tener una tienda D. ropas.

loans.use: Invest in the purchase of food stocks, clothing, and basic materials for their respective businesses.

loans.name: Petronila

texts.es:
Petronila is a member of the La Amistad Communal Bank and lives in the Humano Alfonso Ugarte Settlement in the district and province of Moyabamba in San Martin. Petronila owns a cart which she positions in the city’s Plaza de Armas, and there she sells candy and frugos (fruit beverages) everyday. With her effort and the great customer service she offers, Petronila can still maintain her cart well-stocked. She decided to start her business despite not having the support of her husband because she is a very hard-working person and is very apt for business. Additionally, she likes to generate her own income to nurture her self-esteem, to grow as a person and as a woman, and to help with her household’s expenses to help bring up her children successfully.

With the loan of S/. 1 000.00, which she will repay in 4 months, she will purchase more candy like boxed cookies of different brands and flavors, chocolates, bags of caramels, gum, frugos and other products to better stock her cart because she wants her clients to find what they are looking for. When there is variety, her business grows because sales increase.

Petronila is 29 years old, is separated and has two children who are her pillar of strength to continue working and pull them ahead. Her business has improved, and she is happy with the results she has obtained, for her candies have a fast flow because she is located in a site where many people pass through and is near two schools. Generating her own income helped her improve her financial situation and her self-esteem. Her goal is to own more carts.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Petronila es socia del banco comunal La Amistad , vive en el Asentamiento Humano Alfonso Ugarte Mz F Lt 120 del distrito y provincia de Moyabamba, departamento de San Martín. Petronila tiene un carrito con el que se ubica en la plaza de armas de la ciudad y ahí vende golosinas y frugos (bebidas) todos los días. Con su empeño y buena atención que les brinda a sus clientes Petronila aún puede mantener bien surtido su carrito. Decidió iniciar su negocio a pesar de no contar con el apoyo de su esposo, porque ella es una persona muy trabajadora y hábil para el negocio, además le gusta generar sus propios ingresos para alimentar su autoestima, crecer como persona y mujer y apoyar en los gastos del hogar para sacar adelante a sus hijos. Con el préstamo de S/. 1 000.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará mas golosinas como galletas en cajas de diferentes marcas y sabores, chocolates, bolsas de caramelos, chicles, frugos (bebidas) y otros productos para surtir mejor su carrito porque quiere que sus clientes encuentren lo que buscan, cuando hay variedad el negocio crece ya que aumentan las ventas. Tiene 29 años , es separada y tiene dos hijos que son su fortaleza para seguir trabajando y sacarlos adelante. Su negocio ha mejorado, está contenta con los resultados obtenidos, pues la golosina tiene bastante salida porque ella se ubica donde transita mucha gente y está cerca a dos colegios. Generar sus propios ingresos le ayudó a mejorar su situación económica y su autoestima. Su meta es contar con más carritos.

loans.use: Purchase of candy (cookies, chocolates, caramels, etc.) and other products to stock her cart.

loans.name: Isabel's Group

texts.es:
Isabel is 45 years old and Ricardina is 68 and they both have belonged to the Communal Bank “Radiant Sun” for 5 and 4 years respectively. In their Communal Bank, the two mentioned that they learned how to work, to have their own business, to be disciplined, punctual and above all to save. Initially, Ricardina was selling fruits and sewing bedspreads, but as a result of her sickness she stopped these activities and began selling breakfast at the Santa Clara market. However, Ricardina says that she would like to sell fruits again in a fixed place. This time, Ricardina is taking advantage of the Christmas season, she will sell clothes that she will buy in Huancayo. On the other siD. Isabel has been a craftswoman in textiles since she was young and she does her work on looms, such as tapestries, individual and covers, that are sold in the markets of Ayacucho. Moreover she sells clothes, bread, and other products at the markets of Tambo and Huaytara, and in the markets she buys hens and rams and sells them in Ayacucho. Ricardina and Isabel need loans of 1000 soles each, that they will invest in the purchase of materials for tapestry such as wools, processed threads, dyes and also sweaters, pants, blouses, polos, oats, milk, cinnamon and sugar. Their savings will be used for the studies of their children and for Ricardina’s medical treatment. Ricardina dreams of having her own house, while Isabel dreams that her children will be professionals and can have all goods necessary

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Isabel tiene 45 años y Ricardina tiene 68 años y pertenecen al Banco Comunal “Sol Radiante” desD. hace 5 y 4 años respectivamente. En su Banco Comunal, las dos mencionan que aprendieron a trabajar, a tener un negocio propio, a ser disciplinadas, puntuales y sobre todo a ahorrar. Ricardina inicialmente vendía frutas y tejía colchas, pero a raíz D. su enfermedad dejó D. realizar estas actividades e inició L. venta D. desayuno por el mercado Santa Clara. Sin embargo, Ricardina dice que le gustaría nuevamente vender frutas en un puesto fijo. Esta vez, Ricardina aprovechando L. campaña naviD.ña, venderá ropa que comprará en Huancayo. Por otro lado Isabel desD. muy pequeña es artesana en textiles y realiza trabajos en telares como tapices, individuales y caminos, que son vendidos en los mercados D. Ayacucho. Además elL. venD. ropa, hoja D. coca, pan, entre otros productos en las ferias D. Tambo y Huaytara, y en las ferias compra gallinas, carneros y los venD. en Ayacucho. Ricardina e Isabel necesitan préstamos D. 1000 soles cada una, que serán invertidos en L. compra D. materiales para los tapices como lanas, hilos procesados, tintes y también chompas, pantalones, blusas, polos, avena, leche, caneL. y azúcar. Sus ahorros los utilizarán para los estudios D. sus hijos y para su tratamiento médico. Ricardina sueña con tener una casa propia, mientras que Isabel sueña que sus hijos sean profesionales y pueda tener todos los bienes necesarios.

loans.use: Ricardina and Isabel need loans of 1000 soles each, that will be invested in the purchase of materials for tapestry such as wools, processed threads, dyes and also sweaters, pants, blouses, polos, oats, milk, cinnamon and sugar.

loans.name: Justa Marleni

texts.es:
Señora Justa Marleny is a hard-working and very happy person. She was able to complete her studies only to the first grade of secondary school. She is 34 years old and has 4 children in all, but only two still need her care.

She works from10 in the morning selling cebiche (a Peruvian dish made from raw fish marinated in citrus juice and spices), noodles, papas a la huancaína (a potato dish served on lettuce with a special sauce) and combinations. At noon she prepares and sells lunches and in the evening she works selling anticuchos (a dish consisting of grilled, skewered meat). Her business is located near her house in the Nuevo Jerusalén sector of the district of La Esperanza, province of Trujillo, department of La Libertad.

For many years Justa has worked hard at this business, but only working in the day. With the first loan of 100 soles that she received from Manuela Branches she bought a small grill and began to sell anticuchos in the evenings.

The loan of 400 soles, which she will pay in 4 months, will buy tables, a package of noodles, oil and dishes. Señora Justa dreams of being able to buy a refrigerator and finishing her house so that she can add on a restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Justa Marleny es una persona muy alegre y trabajadora, estudió sólo hasta el primer grado de secundaria, tiene 34 años de edad y 4 hijos en total pero dos aún necesitan de su cuidado.

Ella trabaja desde las 10:00 de la mañana en la venta de cebiche, tallarín, papa a la huancaína y combinados. Al medio día prepara y vende almuerzos y por las noches se dedica a la venta de anticuchos. Su negocio está ubicado cerca de su casa en el sector Nuevo Jerusalén del distrito de La Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad.

Hace muchos años que se dedica a este negocio, pero sólo trabajando en el día. Con el primer préstamo de S/.100 que recibió de Manuela Ramos empieza a vender anticuchos por las noches, para ello compra una pequeña parrilla.

El préstamo de S/.400.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará mesas, un paquete de fideos, aceite y platos.

La señora Justa sueña con comprarse una refrigeradora y con terminar de construir su casa para que más adelante pueda poner un restaurante.

loans.use: To buy assets (tables and dishes) and groceries (noodles and oil).

loans.name: Kusirikuy Group

texts.es:
The Communal Bank for the Kusirikuy Group, which means "be happy" in Quechua, was started 1 year and 8 months ago. Currently, there are 22 members who have had 6 loan cycles together. The founding members were Magdalena, Ana, Norma, Julia, Gloria and Amalia, and this Communal Bank was recognized as a "Model Bank" for having punctual, responsible members. It's a very happy group that is very united.

The members have different businesses, like fruit sales, grocery store, cake making, arrangements for different occasions, screen printing, sculpture, hairdresser, food sales, cosmetics, and market vendors.

Each member has a story to tell, such as Magdalena, who makes cakes and arrangements for weddings, fifteenth birthday parties, and all kinds of occasions. Magdalena started out with a small amount of capital and soon after taking a loan from her Communal Bank bought more supplies and started to promote her services more among her friends. Currently, her business has grown and has many clients.

On the other hand, Karina says that she was the latest member of the Communal Bank and thanks to the training she has received, is now punctual and responsible. She tells about being a market vendor along with her husband, and now with their loan, she will create a new business selling make-up.

The members need different loan amounts. Some are for 200 soles, 400 soles, 800 soles, for a total of 11,000 soles in loans at the Communal Bank.

The loans will be invested in the purchase of flour, dough, floors, make-up, sodas, fruit, rice, sugar, milk, eggs, iron, clothes iron, fabric crayons, etc.

The various members dream of having a car to be able to transport their products, have a large, stable store, have a place of her own, a stable business, and for their children to be professionals.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

El Banco Comunal Kusirikuy que significa “alégrate”en quechua, se inició hace 1 año y 8 meses. Actualmente son 22 socias y ya tienen 6 ciclos juntas. Las socias fundadoras fueron Magdalena, Ana, Norma, Julia, Gloria y Amalia y este Banco Comunal fue premiado como “Banco Modelo” por tener socias puntuales y responsables. Es un grupo muy alegre y son muy unidas. Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta D. frutas, tienda D. abarrotes, preparación D. tortas, arreglos para diferentes compromisos, serigrafía, escultura, peluquería, venta D. comida, cosméticos y feriantes. Cada socia tiene una historia que contar, como es el caso D. Magdalena, quien prepara tortas y realiza arreglos para matrimonios, quince años y todo tipo D. compromisos. Magdalena inició con poco capital y luego D. sacar un préstamo D. su Banco Comunal compró mas insumos y comenzó a promocionar más sus servicios entre sus amigos. Actualmente su negocio ha crecido y tiene muchos clientes. Por otro lado Karina dice que era la socia más “tardona” del Banco Comunal y gracias a las capacitaciones que recibió, ahora es puntual y responsable. Ella cuenta que era feriante junto a su esposo y ahora con su préstamo ella implementará un nuevo negocio D. venta D. maquillaje. Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. préstamos, algunos montos son D. 200 soles, 400 soles, 800 soles haciendo un total D. 11000 soles D. préstamos en el Banco Comunal. Los préstamos lo invertirán en la compra D. harina, masa elástica, pisos, maquillaje, gaseosas, frutas, arroz, azúcar, leche, huevo, fierro, plancha metálica, pinturas para el estampado, etc. Los sueños D. las socias son tener un carro para poder transportar sus productos, tener una tienda granD. y estable, un local propio, un negocio estable y que sus hijos sean profesionales.

loans.use: The members need different loan amounts. Some are for 200 soles, 400 soles, 800 soles, making a total of 11,000 soles in loans from the Communal Bank. The loans will be invested in the purchase of flour, dough, floors, make-up, soft drinks, fruits, rice, sugar, milk, eggs, iron, clothes iron, fabric crayons, etc.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es:
Gloria belongs to the Atenas Portillanas Communal Bank. She lives at Asentamiento Humano La Lupuna in the Yarina Cocha district in Ucayali. She is 36-years-old and is the mother of two children, who are still minors. She is married, and her husband is a merchant. She tells us that his income isn't enough to cover their home's expenses. This is why Gloria, with the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos of 300 nuevos soles, decided to invest in buying and selling clothing.

Currently, she has her business selling clothing which she brings from Lima. She works by taking orders from her clients. After taking care of things in her home, she goes out to deliver and sell her clothing. With this loan of 2,000 nuevos soles, which she will repay in 6 months, she will buy a larger quantity of clothing, ten bedspreads, a dozen wallets, ten sheets, a dozen pieces of jewellery, etc. Gloria feels at peace because her business lets her support her home. She is attracting more clients, and her income is increasing, which benefits her family. This is all thanks to the support of Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Gloria pertenece al Banco Comunal Atenas Portillanas, vive en el Asentamiento Humano La Lupuna del distrito Yarina Cocha, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 36 años de edad y es madre de dos hijos menores de edad, es casada y su esposo es comerciante. Nos dice que el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para cubrir los gastos del hogar, es así que Gloria, con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00, decide invertir en la compra y venta de ropas.

En la actualidad cuenta con su negocio de compra y venta de ropas que trae desde Lima, para lo cual sólo trabaja con pedidos que le hacen sus clientas. Después de ver las cosas en su casa, sale a repartir y vender sus prendas. Con el préstamo de S/. 2.000, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará mayor cantidad de prendas y además diez colchas polares, una docena de carteras, diez sabanas, una docena de joyas, etc. Gloria se siente tranquila ya que el negocio que maneja le permite aportar en su hogar, está captando mayor clientela, sus ingresos están mejorando para el bienestar de su familia y todo gracias al apoyo de Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise (garments, bedspreads, wallets, jewellery, etc.)

loans.name: Mayja Beldith

texts.es:
Mayja belongs to the Communal Bank Atenas Portillanas. She lives at Jr. Sargento Lores Mz. B Lt. 06, Asentamiento Humano Pedro Portillo, in the Calleria district in Ucayali. She is 37-years-old and is the mother of two children, who are still minors. She is separated, which is why the income she had wasn't enough to cover her home's expenses. This is why Mayja, with the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos of 300 nuevos soles, decided to invest in buying and selling fruit.

Currently, she has an Internet cafe, which she attends to with her children, who help her. She also shares the household chores with them so they can then open their business and devote their attention to their clients. With this loan of 1,000 nuevos soles, which she will repay in 6 months, she will buy a computer, a monitor, a keyboard, a printer, and their respective installation so she can supply her business and have a larger clientele. Mayja is very happy because her business is attracting a lot of customers. Her income is increasing along with the well-being of herself and her children, who are her reason for living. This is all thanks to the support of Manuela Ramos.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Mayja pertenece al Banco Comunal Atenas Portillanas, vive en el Jr. Sargento Lores Mz. B Lt. 06, Asentamiento Humano Pedro Portillo del distrito Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 37 años de edad y es madre de dos hijos menores de edad, es separada, de tal modo que el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para cubrir los gastos del hogar, es así que Mayja, con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/. 300.00, decide invertir en la compra y venta de frutas.

En la actualidad cuenta con un negocio de alquiler de cabinas de internet, donde atiende junto con sus hijos que la apoyan, además también con ellos comparten las tareas de la casa para después abrir su local y dedicarse a la atención de sus clientes. Con el préstamo de S/. 1.000, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará un CPU, un monitor, teclado, impresora, y sus respectiva instalación para implementar su negocio y su clientela crezca mas. Mayja está muy feliz, su negocio está captando mayor clientela. Sus ingresos están mejorando para el bienestar de ella y la de sus hijos, que son su razón de ser, y todo gracias al apoyo de Manuela Ramos.

loans.use: Purchase of assets (a computer, monitor, keyboard, and printer)

loans.name: Wendy Ruth

texts.es:
Wendy belongs to the communal bank Nuevas Amigas (New Friends). She lives at 745 Jr. Urubamba in the district of Calleria in Ucayali. She is 26-years-old and is the mother of one son who still depends on her. She is married, and her husband is an accountant, but the income he makes isn't enough to cover the expenses of their home. This is why Wendy, with the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos, decided to invest in the buying and selling of beauty products.

Currently, she has a business selling beauty products, which she delivers to her clients' homes. She attends to her son very happily everyday with the support of her husband, then goes out to offer her products. With this loan of 1,000 nuevos soles, which she will repay in 5 months, she will buy one dozen perfumes, two dozen colognes, half a dozen powders, and a dozen shampoos. Wendy is very happy because she can support her home and her mother. She is very thankful for the support and the ease with which Manuela Ramos lets her access these loans.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Wendy pertenece al Banco Comunal Nuevas Amigas, vive en el Jr. Urubamba 745 del distrito Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Tiene 26 años de edad y es madre de un hijo que aún depende de ella. Es casada, su esposo es contador, pero el ingreso que tiene no alcanza para cubrir los gastos del hogar, es así que Wendy, con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos decide invertir en la compra y venta de productos de belleza.

En la actualidad cuenta con un negocio de venta de productos de belleza que reparte a domicilio. Todos los días, muy contenta, atiende a sus hijos con el apoyo de su esposo, luego sale a ofrecer sus productos. Con el préstamo de S/. 1.000, el cual pagará en 5 meses, comprará una docena de perfumes, dos docenas de colonia, media docena de talco y una docena de champú. Wendy está muy feliz porque puede aportar tanto a su hogar como a su madre. Agradece mucho el apoyo y las facilidades que le brinda Manuela Ramos para acceder a los préstamos.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise (perfume, cologne, powder, etc.)

loans.name: Irma

texts.es:
Irma is 62 years old. She is married and has three children. Irma has worked cultivating and selling garden flowers for more than 40 years.

Currently one of her nephews is helping her with the sale and care of her flowers.

Irma notes that in the city where she lives, despite the existence of various other nurseries and a fair amount of competition, there is a high level of sales.

Irma requests a loan in order to purchase wholesale seed and fertilizer.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Irma tiene 62 años, está casada tiene 3 hijos, ella se dedica ala actividad de cultivo y venta de distintos tipos de flores para jardín hace ya más de 40 años.

Actualmente uno de sus sobrinos es el que se encarga de ayudarla con las ventas y el cuidado de las flores.

Irma, comenta que en la ciudad donde vive, existen varios viveros y hay mucha competencia, pero a pesar de ello hay buen movimiento de ventas.

Solicita el crédito para poder adquirir semillas en grandes cantidades y abono.

loans.use: Purchase seeds and fertilizer.

loans.name: Amelia Rosmeri

texts.es:
Amelia Rosmeri is 28-years-old and only studied through 5th grade. She has two children who still depend on her. She lives in El Porvenir district in the province of Trujillo in La Libertad. Previously, Amelia worked in a shop making shoes, but when she got pregnant, she couldn't continue working. This is why she began to sell food at the entrance of her house. She saved a little money, and with that and the first loan of 300 nuevos soles she received from her communal bank Semillitas Creativas (Little Creative Seeds), she had the capital she needed to sell soft drinks and cookies in addition to food. She saved her profits and, little by little, with the other credits she received, she started a business of selling cleaning products.

With this loan of 1300 nuevos soles, which she will repay in 4 months, she will buy products like wax and brooms to keep supplying her new business.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Amelia Rosmeri tiene 28 años de edad, sólo estudió hasta el quinto grado de secundaria y tiene dos niños que dependen de ella. Vive en el distrito de El Porvenir, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad. Anteriormente la señora Amelia trabajaba alistando calzado en un taller, pero cuando salió embarazada no pudo continuar trabajando, así es que empezó a vender comida en la puerta de su casa y así fue ahorrando un poco de dinero y con el primer préstamo de S/.300.00 que recibió en su Banco Comunal “Semillitas Creativas” completó el capital para vender, a parte de comida, gaseosas y galletas. Fue guardando sus ganancias y poco a poco con los otros créditos que ha recibido ha ido implementando un negocio de venta de productos de limpieza.

Con el préstamo de S/.1,300.00, el cual pagará en cuatro meses, comprará productos como ceras y escobas para continuar implementando su nuevo negocio.

loans.use: Purchase of cleaning products

loans.name: Faustina Natividad

texts.es:
Mrs. Faustina Nautividad is 57 years old and the mother of six children, only one of which is still a dependent. Faustina completed primary school and currently lives in the Carabamba district of the Julcan province in the state of La Libertad.

At a very young age Faustina learned to bake bread from her parents and began her career as a baker. Currently Faustina sells bread and other basic products such as sugar, rice, and oil in the small store which shares space with her home. In addition to managing this business, Faustina also raises animals including cattle, sheep, and swine which she sells in the local fairs.

After being invited by her sister-in-law to join, Fuastina became a part of the Communal Bank “Alfa and Omega.” From this bank she received her first credit of S/. 300.00 ($100.00). In order to best benefit from the loan she used the funds to purchase soda and beer, which she sold in the city-wide party which occurred soon after the date see received the funds.

This loan of S/.1,200.00, which she will repay in four months, will be used to purchase sacks of flour, butter, sugar, and six loads of firewood. Faustina’s dream is to have an electric oven so that she can bake even better bread.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Faustina Natividad, tiene 57 años de edad, estudió primaria completa y tiene 6 hijos, pero sólo uno depende de ella. Vive en el distrito de Carabamba, provincia de Julcán, departamento de La Libertad.

Desde muy pequeña aprendió de sus padres a preparar pan y a eso se dedica. Ahora vende el pan que prepara en una pequeña tienda ubicada en su domicilio, aunque también vende otros productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar, aceite, etc. Aparte de tener este negocio la señora Faustina también cría animales como vacas, carneros y cerdos, los cuales los vende en las ferias de su pueblo.

La señora Faustina ingresó al Banco Comunal “Alfa y Omega” por invitación de su cuñada. En su banco comunal recibió su primer crédito de S/.300.00, con el cual compró cerveza y gaseosa porque la fecha en que lo recibió estaba cerca a la fiesta de su pueblo y tenía que aprovechar estas fiestas para vender estos productos.

El préstamo de S/. 1,200.00, el cual pagará en cuatro meses, comprará sacos de harina, manteca, azúcar, seis cargas de leña, etc. Su sueño es tener un horno eléctrico para elaborar un pan de mejor calidad.

loans.use: Purchase of baking supplies: sugar, flour, butter, firewood, etc.

loans.name: Graciela

texts.es:
Mrs. Graciela R. Ríos is 53 years old and the mother of four children, only one of which is still a dependent. She completed three years of elementary school education. Graciela lives in the country town Túpac Amaru which is in the Carabamba district of the Julcán province of the state of La Libertad.

Thirty years ago Graciela began selling sweaters which she knitted herself and selling bread in the nearby towns. This business maintained her and her family and allowed her to provide her children with an education. Previously, through the use of her savings and a loan from her communal bank, Graciela began new business activities. She purchased curds to make cheese and she sold door-to-door in Trujillo. She also opened a small grocery store in her home.

Graciela was the Community Liaison for Health and helped to negotiate the formation of the Communal Bank of Unity and Effort in her small town. From this bank she obtained her first loan of S/. 300.00 ($100.00), which she used to purchase a scale for her grocery store and wool and thread for knitting. With this loan of S/. 2,300.00 ($775.00) Graciela will purchase small animals such as guinea pigs, sheep, and two hogs. She will resell the animals during the holiday season and repay the loan in four installments.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Graciela R. Ríos tiene 53 años de edad, estudió hasta el tercer grado de primaria, tiene 4 hijos, pero sólo uno depende de ella. Vive en el caserío Túpac Amaru, distrito de Carabamba, provincia de Julcán, departamento de La Libertad.

Hace 30 años inició un negocio vendiendo chompas que ella misma tejía y también pan por los distintos caseríos de su distrito. Con este negocio ha mantenido y ha dado educación a sus hijos. Posteriormente, con lo que fue ahorrando y con los préstamos que recibió en su banco comunal ha ido realizando otras actividades como comprar cuajada para prepara quesos y venderlos casa por casa en la ciudad de Trujillo y también puso una pequeña bodega en su casa.

Fue Promotora Comunitaria de Salud y gestionó la formación del Banco Comunal “Unión y Esfuerzo” en su caserío en su banco comunal obtuvo su primer préstamo de S/.300.00, que le sirvió para comprar lanas e hilos para tejer y una balanza para implementar su bodega. Con el préstamo de S/. 2,300.00, el cual pagará en cuatro cuotas, comprará animales menores como cuyes, carneros y dos chanchos, para venderlos en las fiestas de fin de año.

loans.use: Purchase of small animals (hogs, sheep, and guinea pigs).

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Nilda is a very persistent woman who has learned to strive for a better life since her youth. She has been in turns a saleswoman in a store and cook in a cafeteria. She had also owned a clothing store for a long time. Nilda is a single mother of two children, a boy and a girl.

Currently, Nilda runs a cafeteria. She had taken cuisine classes in a professional center of culinary art. She says her customers are very satisfied with the quality of her dishes. Now she wants to run her own business and, as she puts it: “I am working hard to achieve that goal."

With her loan, Nilda will purchase of raw materials to continuen producing food for her cafeteria. She hopes she can earn sufficient money to realise her dreams to run her own small business before long.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to start a small cafeteria.

loans.name: Kely Amelia

texts.es:
Kely Amelia A. G. is a single 24 year old with one child. She finished high school and currently lives in Caserio Tupac Amaru in the Carabama district of Julcan province of the state of La Libertad.

After finishing school Kely began selling soaps, detergents and milk. With her first loan from Manuela Ramos of S/.300.00 ($100.00) she expanded the selection in her small grocery store to include food products such as: rice, sugar, candles, wheat, oil, etc. Little by little her business has grown and she currently sells curds and shoes which she brings from Trujillo. She also has begun raising and selling small animals (sheep and pigs).

With the loan of S/. 1000.00 ($350.00), which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy wholesale clothing in Trujillo along with three bags of sugar, two of rice, barley, “chochos,” etc. Kely dreams of one day owning a home and business in Trujillo.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Kely Amelia A. G. tiene 24 años de edad, es madre soltera de un niño, estudió secundaria completa. Vive en el Caserío Tupac Amaru del distrito de Carabamba, provincia de Julcán, departamento de La Libertad.

Al salir del colegio, como no pudo continuar estudiando, se dedicó al negocio y comenzó vendiendo una docena de jabón, detergente y leche. Con su primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/.300.00 compró otros productos para continuar surtiendo su bodega con arroz, azúcar, velas, trigo, aceite, etc. Poco a poco ha ido creciendo y ahora vende también cuajada y zapatos que los lleva de la ciudad de Trujillo además se dedica también a la crianza y venta de animales menores como carneros y cerdos.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1000.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará ropa al por mayor en la ciudad de Trujillo, tres bolsas de azúcar, dos sacos de arroz, cebada, chochos, etc. La señora Kely sueña con tener una casa y un negocio grande en la ciudad de Trujillo.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing and other dry goods (sugar, rice, barley, etc).

loans.name: Marta  Delmi

texts.es:
Mirta currently lives in a subsection of La Libertad. She sells clothing from her home, which is set up with a small separation. This separation allows her to run her business and care for her children at the same time. The revenue from the business provides for the needs of the home along with what her life partners earns. Mirta’s plan for the loan is to purchase a greater variety of styles so that she can provide greater choice to the women, since women’s wear is in highest demand. She also has future plans for the construction of a more formal room so that she could better display the clothing and the clients could try the clothing on.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

El objetivo con el crédito es comprar mas ropa que los clientes le solicitan por en cargo y que por ser una cuenta que no pagan de inmediato si no en dos pagos en muchas ocasiones no tiene lo suficiente para poder comprar todo los producto. y volver a invertir de nuevo.

La Sra vive actualmente en una colonia de La Libertad, El Salvador vende ropa y juguetes y otros en seres tiene un chalet, lo que le facilita el poder atender el negocio y no poder descuidar a sus hijos además de generar ingresos para sostener el hogar, mas lo que le aporta su esposo. Su idea con el financiamiento es comprar mas estilos de ropa y así tener variedad en ropa para mujer ya que es la que mas se vende y los juguetes para esta temporada.

loans.use: The loan will be used to purchase additional clothing as requested by her clientele.  Since the clients often do not pay immediately, often times Mirta doesn’t have sufficient funds to fully restock.

location.town: Carretera a Sonsonate casa numero 4 El capulin

loans.name: Akenese

texts.en: Akenese a young mother in Faleapuna. This is her second loan from SPBD. Her business is sewing, and most of her clients are village people. Sometimes she earns a lot, especially when she sews a group's uniforms. She started her business in 2002 in a very small open house but now she has extended that and has a special room for her business. She earns $500 WST ($200 USD) in good days with the right customers. She set a goal for her business to move into Apia for a change. She never forgets the financial assistance from SPBD.

loans.use: To buy sewing supplies and for home improvement

loans.name: Akenese

texts.en: Akenese a young mother of Faleapuna this is her second loan from SPBD. Her business is sewing, and most of her client is village people,sometimes she earned a lot specially when she  sewn a group uniform. She start her business in 2002 in a very small open house but now she extend that and have a special room for her business. She earns $500 WST ($200 USD) in good days with the right customers so she set a goal for her business to move into Apia for a change so never forget the financial assistant from SPBD Office for their support

loans.use: To buy sewing supplies and for home improvement

loans.name: Doris Azucena

texts.es:
Señora Doris Azucena lives in the small village of Cochaya, district of Salpo, province of Otuzco, department of La Libertad. She is 39 years old and has 4 children that still depend on her. She was only able to complete her schooling through grade school.

Señora Doris started a business with the first loan of 300 soles that she received from her Communal Bank, "Virgin del Carmen". She works preparing cheeses and milk curd, partly with milk produced by her cattle and partly with milk that she buys from some people in her community. She sells her products to some wine cellars of different villages and also to a list of clients in the city of Trujillo that she has obtained through her time and dependability.

With the loan of 1,000 soles, which she will pay in 4 months, Doris will buy milk curd for making cheese and three rams to sell their meat. She will also buy concentrated feed for the cows.

Señora Doris is an associate of the "Eleodora Alfaro López" mothers’ club, where she has served previously as president and treasurer. Her dream is to have a small truck that she can use to transport merchandise to the different villages and to Trujillo.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Doris Azucena vive en el poblado menor de Cochaya, distrito de Salpo, provincia de Otuzco, departamento de La Libertad. Tiene 39 años de edad, sólo estudió primaria completa y tiene 4 hijos que aún dependen de ella.

La señora Doris inicia un negocio con el primer préstamo de S/.300.00 que recibió en su Banco Comunal “Virgen del Carmen”. Ella se dedica a la preparación de quesos y cuajada, una parte con leche que produce su ganado y otra con leche que compra de algunos pobladores de su comunidad. Sus productos los vende en algunas bodegas de diferentes caseríos y también a una cartera de clientes en la ciudad de Trujillo que ha obtenido con el tiempo y la constancia.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,000.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará tres carneros para vender su carne y cuajada para hacer los quesos, también comparará concentrado para alimentar a las vacas.

La señora Doris es socia del club de madres “Eleodora Alfaro López”, anteriormente fue presidenta y tesorera. Su sueño es tener una camioneta para movilizarse con la de mercadería a los diferentes caseríos y a Trujillo.

loans.use: To buy small animals and concentrated animal food.

loans.name: Evelina Ma

texts.en: Evelina is a new member at the Fusi Saluafata Centre. With the approval from the Centre Chief and the members, now she can join SPBD. She is in her mid-fifties and a grandmother, but she is very happy with this opportunity because she never had a chance to get a loan from any financial company in Samoa. Her business was started long ago but she needs to upgrade or replace some of her equipment. She is learning how to budget income and expenses for the business. Evelina also gets some assistance from family overseas.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies for her plantation

loans.name: Fuifui

texts.en: Manunu village is inland on the east side of Upolu island. It's one of the most promising centres in the history of SPBD in Samoa. Fuifui is one of their clients and this is her second loan from SPBD. She will use the money  for her children to return to school next year. She will spend the rest to replace some of her plantation equipment. From her business in harvest season she gets nearly $1000 a week. This helps with her family's everyday living expenses and covers her church and family affairs contributions.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her plantation and for her children's school expenses

loans.name: Esmeralda Luz

texts.es:
Mrs. Esmeralda Luz studied until she was a junior in high school. She has two children, one of whom is still her dependent. The 43 year old mother, Mrs. Luz is incredibly dedicated to her work. She lives in Poblado Menor Cochaya in the Salpo district of La Libertad.

Mrs. Luz used her first loan from the Communal Bank of the Virgen Carmen of S/.300.00 ($100) to start a small grocery store. She soon decided close the grocery store and move on to selling cheeses and curds in Trujillo because the prices were very unstable during the season she opened.

With this loan of S./1,000.00 ($350.00), which will be repaid within 4 months, Mrs. Luz will purchase a few rams and a young bull. She will then resell their meat. She is changing industries once again because the demand for dairy products is currently low and milk is quite expensive.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Esmelda Luz estudió hasta el tercer año de secundaria y tiene 2 hijos, uno aún depende de ella. Es una mujer muy empeñosa en el trabajo que realiza, tiene 43 años de edad y vive en el Poblado Menor Cochaya del distrito de Salpo, departamento de La Libertad.

La señora Esmelda con su primer préstamo de S/.300.00 que obtuvo en el Banco Comunal “Virgen del Carmen”, implementó una pequeña bodega, pero como los precios en esa temporada estaban muy inestables prefirió cerrar y dedicarse a la venta de quesos y cuajada los cuales los lleva a vender a Trujillo.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,000.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará algunos carneros y un torito para vender su carne, debido a que por este tiempo no hay mucha demanda de quesos y quesillos, además que la leche se pone cara.

loans.use: Purchase of sheep

loans.name: Vaitupua

texts.en: Vaitupua is a mother from Mulifanua village. This is her second loan from SPBD. She used her first loan to expand her vegetable garden. She earns $500 WST ($200 USD) per week in harvest season. She wants to spend this loan to upgrade her business, to renovate her home, and support her grandchildren at school.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her vegetable garden and for home improvement

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.es:
Consuelo is 51-years-old. She lives in La Esperanza district in the province of Trujillo in La Libertad. She has 6 children, but only 4 are still her dependents. She only studied through elementary school because she no longer had support from her parents.

Consuelo started a business selling groceries, but her husband worked in a shoe factory, where he learned to make them. When she obtained her first loan of 300 nuevos soles in the Communal Bank Mujeres Valerosas (Courageous Women), she decided to start a small shop where she made shoes, which she learned how to do from her husband. Little by little, with her skills and subsequent loans, she bought more equipment and material. She now produces a large quantity of shoes and distributes them in markets in Trujillo and on Peru's border with Ecuador.

With this loan of 500 nuevos soles, which she will repay in 4 months, she will buy shoe forms, leather, and glue to make her shoes. Consuelo dreams about having a larger store with all of her machinery to be able to make shoes of better quality.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

La señora Consuelo tiene 51 años de edad, vive en el distrito de La Esperanza, provincia de Trujillo, departamento de La Libertad. Tiene 6 hijos, pero sólo 4 dependen de ella. Estudió sólo educación primaria debido a que no tuvo más apoyo de sus padres.

La señora Consuelo se inicia en el negocio vendiendo abarrotes, pero su esposo trabajaba en una fábrica de calzado donde aprendió a confeccionarlos. Cuando obtiene su primer préstamo de S/.300.00 en el Banco Comunal “Mujeres Valerosas”, deciden implementar un pequeño taller artesanal y dedicarse a la confección de calzado, con ello implementó el taller e inició la confección de calzado aprendiendo de su esposo, poco a poco con sus utilidades y los siguientes préstamos recibidos ha ido comprando más utensilios y material y actualmente producen en mayor cantidad y distribuye en los mercados de Trujillo y en la frontera de Perú con Ecuador.

Con el préstamo de S/. 500.00, el cual pagará en 4 cuotas, comprará hormas, cuero y algo de pegamento para la confección de los zapatos. La señora Consuelo sueña con tener un taller mas amplio con toda su maquinaria y poder fabricar calzado de mejor calidad.

loans.use: Purchase of materials (leather and glue)

loans.name: Ernesta

texts.en:
Ernesta is an elderly widow, mother of eleven adult children, seven of them girls. Ernesta runs a unique business which in its own way, reflects her patient character: she makes and sells ropes.

Ernesta’s ropes are very famous in her community for their durability. She says the most important thing is not to focus on preparing a lot of ropes, but on making sure that they will be useful to the customers. She also says business is very profitable. She travels outsiD. her community to purchase a small truck full of thread with which she makes the ropes. People in her community use the ropes for various purposes.

She is requesting a loan to buy a large quantity of thread so that she can produce more ropes to sell during the holidays. Additional income will help Ernesta maintain a comfortable lifestyle.

loans.use: To get a sufficient amount of thread to continue her rope-selling business.

loans.name: Tolusefulu's Group

texts.en: For these three new members to Manono Tai Centre, this their first loan from the SPBD programme. They grew up on Manono island which is located between the two main island of Samoa. Their main talent is fishing and they are very glad that they have an opportunity of not having to depend on their families overseas. They wish to maintain and improve their businesses, which will improve the standard of living for their families. They also have children at school. School fees and lunches are one of their main expenses, as well as church donations and contributions for their extended families.

loans.use: To buy fishing gear

loans.name: Sela

texts.en: Sela is forty years of age from the village of Aele. She has eight children. Four on them are working at the time, and the other four are attending school. She works three days a week weeding the grass, and she sells her product once a week. She also receives remittances from her working children and some from her relatives overseas. This is her first loan and she is using it to maintain her plantation business. She is hard-working and her dream in the future is to be successful with the business.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her peanut plantation

loans.name: Claudia Beatriz

texts.es:
Mrs. H. lives with her husband and child their families home in the town of Lourdes. She has spent about two years selling clothing, a business which has helped the family to continue to move forward after her husband went unemployed for several months. It is grown into their main source of support. The loan will be invested in additional items of women’s clothing such as shirts, skirts and other items that are in style. Mrs. H. is very confident in this investment and use it to expand her reach into other sectors.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. H. vive en una colonia de Lourdes, su negocio es venta de ropa, actualmente vive con su esposo y un hijo en casa familiar, tiene aproximadamente dos años de dedicarse a esta venta el cual le a ayudado para poder salir adelante cuando su esposo se a quedado sin empleo por meses, ya que es la fuente de ingreso de la cual se alimentan , el crédito lo invertirá en comprar ropa de mujer como camisas faldas y otros que están de moda ella se muestra convencida de invertir y así ampliarse a otros sectores

loans.use: Purchase of clothing for men, women and children.

location.town: Col. Las Arboledas Pasaje 2 Casa numero 17

loans.name: Taofi

texts.en: Taofi E. is one of the successful clients of SBPD. She started with a snack shop until she managed to open a shop, which is the first shop at Aele. She has four children and her husband is working as a Security Officer. He gets paid every two weeks and this is another alternative income for her. She is open six days a week and from six o’clock in the morning until 10.00 in the evening. She is one of the hard-working members of the programme and she is making good use of this opportunity.

loans.use: To restock her shop

loans.name: Irene

texts.en:
Irene is a hardworking and very experienced businesswoman. For more than ten years, she has been preparing and selling delicious dishes to the people of her community. Irene and her husband have eight sons who study and work.

Irene plans on enlarging her business in order to serve more customers and increase her income. She plans on using her loan to buy more raw materials to keep on preparing her food. She wants to keep working hard to earn more and improve her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: Purchase raw materials to continue producing food in a small cafeteria.

loans.name: Fofoga

texts.en: Fofoga M. is a thirty-eight year old mother from the village of Elise Fou. Her business is a food stall at Savalalo Flea Market, five days a week. Her husband helps out with the business every week. She usually manages to get about $600 WST ($240 USD) net profit a week plus remittances from her sister in New Zealand. Her customers are the public coming to town for shopping and especially the school children who come to catch their buses. She is still struggling because all of her children are attending school. This is her second loan and she is doing well with her loan repayments.

loans.use: To buy supplies and ingredients for her food stall business

loans.name: Matauina

texts.en:
Matauaina is one of the successful businesswomen at the Fugalei Market. She sells different varieties of food, and she is open six days of the week including Saturdays. She earns $800 WST ($320 USD) of profit a week and this money will be used for church donations, Family Weekly expenses and also for the children’s school things and fees. Her husband works seven days a week and he usually gets about $125 WST ($50 USD) per week.

This is her first loan, and she is grateful for the opportunity to have access to loan money which she was not able to have before. Now she is making sure that her income will be an alternative income so that she can repay her loan.

loans.use: To buy supplies and ingredients for her food stall businesss

loans.name: Sauleola

texts.en: Sauleola lives near the town area. She is from the village of Vaigaga and she is fifty-five years of age. She is a grandmother but she is still active at running her business, while providing lunches for all the students of Vaigaga Primary School. She sells Ice cakes, pork buns, chocolates, snacks, and ice cream which are the favourite munchies for children. She sells her products five days a week and she manage to earn $500 WST ($200 USD) a week. This is her major source of income and she is still running her business successfully. She is one of the active members of the programme and she is very honest and hard working.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her canteen business and for home improvement

loans.name: Faamau

texts.en: Faamau M. is from the village of Elise Fou. She is 39 years old and a mother of 4 children. She runs a food stall at the Savalalo market, so all her customers are the ones who come to the market for shopping. Before joining SPBD, she used to be financially supported by members of her family from overseas. Now she is not relying on her family overseas anymore, and she will continue to run her business and support her children.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her food stall business and for home improvement

loans.name: Felipa

texts.en:
When she started her small business two years ago, Felipa was just selling sandwiches and juices. Shortly after, she decided to run a grocery store because “people of the community really needed such a thing” she explains. Felipa kept fighting to make her business successful, and one year later she obtained an FSMA loan, which helped her assure the subsistence of her store. Felipa has three children who range in age from 13 to 17.

Felipa envisions her grocery store becoming the biggest of her community. She thinks that December is a suitable month to increase her sales volume and her income. She has requested a loan to buy more goods with which to replenish her store. Felipa is putting money aside to support her eldest son's university studies next year.

loans.use: To replenish a grocery store to keep on satisfying the customers needs.

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.es:
Ana Maria is a married, 47-year-old mother of 2. She and her husband own a furniture and upholstery business. She would like to expand her business, and in order to contribute to its growth, she is requesting a loan so that she may purchase the materials necessary for manufacturing furniture, thus being able to move forward and establish their business as a prosperous one in the Memorial Sandino neighborhood.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Ana Maria tiene 47 años de edad, es casada y tiene 2 niños; y junto con su marido tiene un negocio de elaboración de muebles y tapicería en general. Desea que su negocio crezca, y como parte de ese crecimiento solicita su crédito para comprar materia prima para la elaboración de sus muebles y así poder seguir adelante y poder establecer su tapicería como un negocio próspero en el barrio Memorial Sandino.

loans.use: Purchase of upholstery materials

loans.name: Fela María

texts.en:
Fela is a very young entrepreneur who struggles to make a living and take care of her two children. She runs a beauty salon whichshe started just a few months ago. Her husband, also very young, works for a watch-making company.

Fela aims to offer more services in her salon so that she can attract new clients. She has requested a loan to buy an automatic hairdryer to replace a damaged one. She also plans to purchase other goods such as rinse, shampoo, face lotion and other beauty products. Given this loan, she will be in a condition to attract new customer to her salon, and will also be able to improve her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: To buy a new automatic hairdryer and other products for a beauty salon.

loans.name: Francisca Del Rosari

texts.es:
Francisca del Rosario has a small home in the Hialeah neighborhood in Managua. Her home is very small and the majority is made of zinc laminate. Ms. Francisca is a seamstress, a business with which she maintains her 4 children that still economically depend on her. One of her biggest objectives is to give a better quality of life to her family. She needs the money to construct concrete walls and from there to continue advancing in the total improvement of her home.

Translated from Spanish by Lauren Conover, Kiva Volunteer.

Francisca del Rosario tiene una pequeña vivienda en el barrio Hialeah de Managua. Su vivienda es muy pequeña y está hecha en gran parte por láminas de zinc. Doña Francisca es costurera, negocio con el cual otorga el sustento a 4 hijos que todavía dependen económicamente de ella. Uno de sus grandes objetivos es darle una mejor calidad de vida a su familia. Necesita el dinero para construir las paredes del cuarto de concreto, y así poder ir avanzando en el mejoramiento total de su vivienda.

loans.use: Construction of walls in a room of a house

loans.name: Martha

texts.es:
Martha is 40 years old, and she dedicates herself to the sale of clothing and cosmetics. Her husband is an industrial worker. They have one young child. She would like to obtain a loan to make some repairs to their home which is in bad disrepair. She would like to add a better bathroom/sanitary facility, which currently consist of a latrine and sheet metal walls.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Martha tiene 40 años de edad, y se dedica a la venta de Ropa y cosméticos. Su marido trabaja en una vulcanización. Ellos tienen un niño menor de edad. Ella quisiera obtener el crédito porque quiere empezar a reparar su casa que está en muy mal estado; quiere empezar haciendo el servicio Sanitario y el Baño que actualmente está hecho con paredes de zinc y el servicio higiénico es una letrina.

loans.use: Build a bathroom/sanitary facility for her home.

loans.name: Candida

texts.en:
Candida is 21 years old has three daughters. She sells children’s toys such as Spiderman, Spartacus and Max Steel toy dolls in her neighborhood.

Candida needs funds to purchase soft toys to sell during the holidays. She plans to buy Christmas-related toys which she hopes people will buy as presents for their children. Candida envisions her business becoming a large toy store in a few years.

loans.use: Purchase doll toys, cuddly toys to sell during the holidays.

loans.name: Israel

texts.es:
The client currently lives with his wife and two children. He is need of a mode of transportation that will take him quickly from one place to another. His business of electrical, plumbing, and other types of repairs require him oftentimes to make house calls. He finds himself having a difficult time of arriving in a timely manner for his customers. For this reason, he seeks a loan to be able to purchase a car that would allow him to arrive more quickly and cover his route more efficiently. With an improved mode of transportation, he would be able to improve his earnings, give his children a better education, and cover the living expenses of his family.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

El cliente vive actualmente con su esposa y dos hijos, se le hace necesario el poder transportarse de un lugar a otro de manera rápida ya que su negocio es de reparaciones eléctricas servicio de fontanería y otros, en muchas ocasiones los clientes le solicitan el servicio a domicilio y no puede dárselo de manera oportuna, es por eso que solicita el crédito para poder comprar un vehículo que le permita llegar mas rapìdo y poder cubrir la ruta además de esa manera podría tener mas ingresos y poder dar a sus hijos una mejor educación y solventar las necesidades de la familia .

loans.use: Purchase a car to better serve his electrical and plumbing repair customers who require house calls.

location.town: Col. 20 de Octubre  Calle Principal Poligon 2 lote

loans.name: Damaris

texts.es:
Damaris is 39 years old. She owns a small convenience store and she has grown her business with much effort. With her earnings from the store, she sells fried foods at night. On weekends she sells nacatamales, a typical food of the region. She needs the loan to build a protective wall around the back part of her house. This would allow her to better secure her business, located in the Laureles Sur neighborhood where she lives.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Damaris tiene 39 años y posee una pulpería que ha hecho crecer con mucho esfuerzo, con las ganancias de su negocio vende fritangas por las noches y también vene nacatamales los fines de semana. Necesita su crédito para levantar un muro de protección en la parte trasera de su vivienda y le permita tener seguridad en su negocio, en el barrio Laureles Sur, donde reside.

loans.use: Finish construction of a wall around the back of her house.

loans.name: Maria Magdalena

texts.es:
Mrs. Maria Magdalena belongs to the Comunal Bank of Valiant Women, she lives in the San Martin region, Huallaga province, Saposoa district. Her business is located at 304 Humberto Torres and it is a clothing store. Thanks to the support of her spouse, three children and her own effort, she was able to increase her sales y expand her business. Now she has more customers and orders. With the loan of 800 Soles, which she will repay in 6 months, she will buy clothing for women, men and children in a variety of sizes, styles and for a variety of occasions and fill all her orders. Mrs. Maria Magdalena is 37 years old; she lives with her spouse and her three children; she works daily, demonstrating that she can grow as a businesswoman and reach her goals, to which there are no limits.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Drejet, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora María Magdalena pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres Valientes, vive en la región San Martín, provincia Huallaga, distrito Saposoa. Su negocio está ubicado en el Pasaje Humberto Torres No. 304 y se dedica a la venta de ropa. Gracias al apoyo de su esposo y de sus tres hijos y de su propio esfuerzo sus ventas se incrementaron y su negocio creció. Actualmente tiene mayor cantidad de clientes y pedidos. Con el préstamo de S/. 800.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará ropa para damas, caballeros y niños en variedad de tallas, modelos y para diversas ocasiones y de esa manera cumplir con todos sus pedidos. La señora María Magdalena tiene 37 años, vive con su esposo y sus tres hijos, trabaja diariamente demostrando de esa manera que ella puede crecer como empresaria y cumplir sus metas y que para ello no hay límites.

loans.use: Buy clothing for women, men and children.

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.es:
Yolanda belongs to the Communal Bank of Valiant Women; she lives in the San Martin region, Huallaga province, Saposoa district. Her business is located at 670 Lima Avenue and she sells clothes and shoes. Thanks to the support of her spouse and her own effort she was able to expand her business, which began with little inventory and in a small space and now has a bigger space and a large clientele. With the loan of 800 soles, which she will repay in 6 months, she will buy different models of shoes and a greater variety of clothing styles, for a variety of occasions, and a few specific requests of her customers. Yolanda is 40 years old, she lives with her spouse, and works every day starting very early in the morning so that she can get ahead and achieve her goal of having her two children successfully finish medical school.

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Drejet, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Yolanda pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres Valientes, vive en la región de San Martín, provincia Huallaga, distrito Saposoa. Su negocio está ubicado en Av. Lima No. 670 y se dedica a la venta de ropas y zapatos. Gracias al apoyo de su esposo y a su propio esfuerzo logró aumentar su negocio ya que empezó con poco y un local pequeño y ahora tiene un local más grande y gran cantidad de clientela. Con el préstamo de S/. 800.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará zapatos en diferentes modelos y tallas y ropa en variedad de modelos y para diferentes ocasiones y algunos pedidos directos de sus clientes. La señora Yolanda tiene 40 años, vive con su esposo, trabaja todos los días desde muy temprano para salir adelante y poder cumplir con la meta que sus dos hijos que están estudiando medicina terminen con éxito.

loans.use: Buy shoes and clothes

loans.name: Luisa

texts.es:
Mrs. Luisa belongs to the communal bank “Las Saposoinas”, and lives in the San Martín region of the province of Huallaga. Her business is located on the corner of Bolivar and Bolognesi streets. She dedicates herself to selling clothing for children and adults.

Thanks to the support of her son, and to her own diligent efforts, her business is growing. She experiences increased sales activity during the holiday season.

With the loan of 1,500 soles, to be repaid over six months, she will buy more clothing for children and adults (both men’s and women’s) in a variety of styles and for every occasion.

Mrs. Luisa is 36 years old, is single and lives alone with her son. She demonstrates that, by working hard every day, there are no limits to what one can achieve.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Luisa pertenece al Banco Comunal Las Saposoinas, vive en la región San Martín, provincia del Huallaga y distrito de Saposoa. Su negocio está ubicado en la esquina de Jr.Bolivar y Bolognesi s/n y se dedica a vender ropa de niños y adultos. Gracias al apoyo de su hijo y al esfuerzo que ella pone en su negocio está saliendo adelante en sus ventas. Actualmente incrementó su negocio para las fiestas navideñas ya que en esa fecha vende mas. Con el préstamo de S/.1,500.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará más ropa de vestir para niños y adultos (hombres y mujeres) en variedad de modelos y para toda ocasión. La señora Luisa tiene 36 años, vive sola con su hijo, no tiene pareja, trabaja diariamente, demostrando de esa manera, que para cumplir metas no hay límites y se puede alcanzar lo que se propone.

loans.use: Purchase clothing.

loans.name: Lanly

texts.es:
Mrs. Lanly belongs to the communal bank “Mujeres Valientes” (“Brave Women”), and lives in the San Martín section of the province of Huallaga. She dedicates herself to the sale of agrochemical products (fertilizers, herbicides, etc.).

Thanks to the support of her husband who is a veterinarian, as well as to her own efforts, she has grown her business and now has many regular customers.
