loans.use: Purchase of pet food, vaccinations, shampoo, powder, collars, pet apparel, etc.

loans.name: Manuel

texts.es:
Mr. Manual C. lives in his own home in the Milluni area of the city of El Alto with his two children. Manual works as a builder on private jobs. The home on his property has only two rooms and electricity. Because he lives in the surrounding areas of El Alto, there isn't a perimeter wall (fence). The loan will be used for the construction of a perimeter wall and a primary access door to his home. This is the second time that he has asked for a loan. The socioeconomic analysis indicates that he is qualified to receive a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Kim Baker, Kiva volunteer.

El señor Manuel C. vive en casa propia en la zona de Milluni de la Ciudad de El Alto con sus dos hijos, el señor Manuel trabaja como constructor en obras particulares. La vivienda de su propiedad solo cuenta con dos habitaciones y el servicio de electricidad domiciliaria, ya que vive en la zona peri urbana de El Alto y no cuenta con un muro perimetral El crédito solicitado será destinado a la construcción del muro perimetral y una puerta de acceso principal a su domicilio. Esta es la segunda ocasión que solicita un préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado, lo califica favorablemente y puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.

loans.use: Building of a perimeter wall (fence) and a principal access door to the house.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy is 51 and widowed with seven children. She also cares for four orphans. She owns two businesses, a restaurant and a timber/furniture  business. She buys the timber already felled and then mills it into boards. She then transports the timber to the nearby town of Ntugamo where she has her workers make it into furniture, usually chairs, and beds. These kinds of furniture makers are quite common along the roadside, displaying their finished products out by the road. Since most have rather rudimentary tools and no electrical tools, the furniture is lacking in high quality, but is in high demand nevertheless. With her loan, Joy plans to pay her workers and to pay for transport of her timber.

loans.use: Joy plans to use her loan to pay for transport of her lumber and to pay her workers.

loans.name: Evas

texts.en:
Evas is 21 years old and married with one child. For the past year she has operated a retail store, where she sells dry staples such as sugar, maize flour, rice and salt. She buys the dry staples in 100kg bags and sells by weight to customers. I have sat in some of these retail stores, relaxing, having a soda, passing the time. There are often a couple of chairs and a coffee table at which patrons can sit and enjoy their soda. These stores are usually operated by women, who run the store while looking out for their children playing outside on the street.

However, the best time is at night, when shops are only lit by lanterns. The atmosphere is alive at night and everyone enjoys being out in the cool air. Music plays, charcoal stoves roast skewered barbequed meat and chicken and people congregate in groups enjoying each others' company. There is very little crime as there is not much to steal and everyone is in the same boat. Evas is requesting a loan with which she plans to buy more staples such as sugar, flour, rice and salt for her store.

loans.use: Evas plans to use her loan to buy more staples such as sugar, flour, rice and salt for her store.

loans.name: Martina

texts.es:
Martina is 48 years old, she is married and has 3 children. She has been making and selling "chipas" for over 15 years. "Chipas" are a typical Paraguayan food which resembles cheese bread. It is made with cornstarch, eggs and cheese.

She inherited this job from her parents, they are very well known people in the area. They offer very high quality "chipas" and this has given them a very good reputation.

She requests this loan in order to be able to purchase ingredients such as cheese, cornstarch, vegetable oil, and other ingredients necessary to make these "chipas". This time of the year they are very popular and the sales of these tend to go up

Translated from Spanish by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Martina tiene 48 años, está casada y tiene 3 hijos. Se dedica a la fabricación y venta de chipas hace ya más de 15 años, la chipa es una comida típica del Paraguay parecido a un pan de queso, hecho con almidón, huevos y queso.

El oficio de la elaboración de chipas lo heredó de sus padres, quiénes son muy conocidos en la zona ya que la calidad de sus productos ya es tradicional en la zona.

Ella hoy solicita un crédito con los que desea adquirir en gran cantidad los ingredientes como queso, almidón, aceite vegetal y otros ingredientes para la elaboración de las chipas ya que en esta época del año las ventas de las mismas aumenta considerablemente.

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients such as: cornstarch, cheese, vegetable oil, etc.

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
This is Neema M.’s restaurant.  Well, the kitchen anyway.  The eating area is some wooden benches and a table a few metres to the left of the photo.  But don’t be put off by the basic setting (or the chickens wandering around).  The food is delicious - ugali (a kind of cooked sticky dough made from maize flour), plantain (a kind of savoury cooked banana) and rice, all served with delicious sauces, vegetables, meat and beans.

Neema established the business in 2005 and now requires a loan of $550 to purchase additional equipment (bowls, pots and plates), as well as some basic ingredients in bulk (rice, flour, beans).  She is married to her husband, Paulo, with whom she has five children between the ages of 11 and 23.  Neema and Paulo also care for two of Neema’s nieces.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing.  Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets.  This leads to poor financial support, which in turn leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys from and leases equipment to women.  Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from the said client extending a loan to her, and then leases beck the same equipment – a process called a "sale and leaseback arrangement".

loans.use: To purchase equipment and ingredients for her cafe.

loans.name: Odilonia

texts.es:
Odilonia is a single mother of a beautiful daughter. She lives with her parents and owns a small convenience store where she sells groceries such as soft drinks, fruits, vegetables, canned goods, noodles, flour, etc. This summer season, the products that are sold the most are cold drinks. She also plans to sell homemade ice cream next month.

She is currently requesting this loan so that she may purchase soft drinks, juice, mineral water, and beer because those are the most popular items this season.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Odilonia, es madre soltera una hermosa hija; vive con sus padres y es propietaria de un despensa donde vende todo tipo de artículos de primera necesidad y de consumo.

Entre las cosas que vende podemos citar gaseosas, frutas, vegetales, productos enlatados, fideos, harina, etc. En esta época de verano lo que más vende son las bebidas bien frías, más adelante desea vender helados de su propia elaboración.

El proyecto de venta y elaboración de los helados lo concretará en el mes siguiente. Hoy ella solicita un crédito para poder surtir su despensa con bebidas como gaseosas, jugos, agua mineral y cerveza ya que son los de mayor venta en esta época.

loans.use: Purchase of beverages—soft drinks, beer, mineral water, juice

loans.name: Pilli

texts.en:
Pilli M.’s beautiful smile entices customers into her shop, and her beautiful clothes keep them there.  She established the business in 2004 and has been making and selling clothes ever since.  Now, Pilli requires a loan to purchase additional materials to sew some new additions.  She is married to her husband, Omari, with whom she has two children - Ibrahim, aged 5, and Ishaq, 18 months.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing.  Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets.  This leads to poor financial support, which in turn leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys from and leases equipment to women.  Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from the said client extending a loan to her, and then leases back the same equipment – a process called a "sale and leaseback arrangement".

loans.use: To purchase material to sew  a new range of clothes to sell.

loans.name: Twawiya

texts.en:
Twawiya B. is a perfect example of why microfinance works, and why the large majority of clients repay their loans.  A lot of people who hear about microfinance (or kiva.org) for the first time ask anxiously, “but how do you make sure people pay back?  Won’t they just take the money?”  The implication is that the clientele who access microfinance (usually the poor) are less trustworthy, efficient or educated than ‘ordinary’ people.  Whether or not this is true is somewhat irrelevant for a number of reasons.  

Firstly, most MFIs have due diligence processes in place to assess client risk, as well as measures such as collateral arrangements and group lending (where a defaulted loan is borne by the group as a whole) to address this risk.  More important than any of these deterrents, however, is an incentive.  The incentive is for clients to be able to start a business, build a business, and repay their loan so that they can get another and another and another… The incentive is to have on-going access to financial services from which they had previously been excluded.

Twawiya began this journey in 2002 when she opened a shop selling a variety of foodstuffs.  Since then, she has received and repaid four loans of progressively increasing amounts from SELFINA, which she has used to expand her business.  Twawiya now purchases all her stock in bulk, which has enabled her to increase her profits.  

This time, Twawiya requires a loan of $1075 to purchase stocks of soda, flour and sugar.  Her business makes it possible for Twawiya to provide for her three daughters - Corona, 12, Caroline, 9, Theresa, 6 - and her niece, Elizabeth, aged 10.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing.  Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; thus, they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets.  This leads to poor financial support, which in turn leads to poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys from and leases equipment to women.  Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from the said client extending a loan to her, and then leases back the same equipment – a process called a "sale and leaseback arrangement".

loans.use: To purchase stocks of soda, flour and sugar in bulk.

loans.name: Inviolata

texts.en:
This is 51 year-old Mama K..  In 2006, she established a brick-making business to supplement her teacher’s salary.  Mama K. doesn’t actually make the bricks herself.  It’s heavy and time-consuming work, so she has one employee who takes care of the production side of the business.  She requires a loan to expand production and possibly hire another employee.  Mama K. is a widow with three children, and cares for her granddaughter Emilian, who is 15 years-old.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

loans.use: To expand production of her brick-making business.

loans.name: Pablina

texts.es:
Mrs. Pablina C. is 48 years old, is married and has two daughters. She owns a milking yard with more than 8 milk cows, 5 calves and one bull.

Pablina describes her job as very demanding due to the fact that she is moving from the early hours of daybreak, since the care and milking of the cows are early morning activities.

This occupation and that of her husband who is a passenger bus driver, is what supports the home. She sells the milk to her neighbors and the local food stores. Her daughters handle the distribution. They have a motorbike which they use to make the milk deliveries.

Pablina wants to get two additional milk cows. This will allow her to increase the production in response to the considerable increase in milk demand.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Pablina tiene 48 años, está casada y tiene 2 hijas. Ella posee un tambo comprendido de más de 8 vacas lecheras, 5 terneros y un toro.

Pablina nos cuenta que éste trabajo es muy sacrificado debido a que uno debe estar en movimiento desde las primeras horas de la madruga ya que el proceso de cuidar y controlar como así el ordeñar las vacas son las primeras actividades del día.

Este oficio y junto con el de su marido que es chofer de bus de pasajeros, son los que mantienen la casa. La leche lo vende a sus vecinos y a las despensas de la zona. De la distribución se encargan sus hijas, que poseen una motocicleta con la que distribuyen la leche.

Pablina desea adquirir dos vacas lecheras más, de esta forma podrá aumentar la producción ya que la demanda de la leche ha aumentado considerablemente.

loans.use: Purchase of two milk cows.

texts.en:
Water, water everywhere, but not a cold drop to drink.  In 2004, Anna W. established a business selling bottled water and has realized that she could increase her sales if she were able to refrigerate the water.  She is therefore requesting a loan of $625 to purchase a fridge.  Anna is a 37 year-old single mother with one son, Ibnrahim, who is 17.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
This is 38 year-old Catherine K..  She is a nurse by profession and a pharmacist by trade.  Earlier this year, she opened her pharmacy in order to supplement her nurse’s salary.  It was a wise decision as she is able to use her knowledge and experience from nursing to efficiently manage stock and provide excellent customer service.  Catherine now requires a loan of $900 to purchase additional stock and continue building her business.  She is married to her husband, Timothy, with whom she has three children - Morice, aged 12, and twins, Tumaini and Neeema, aged 6.

loans.name: Yusta

texts.en:
This is 34 year-old Yusta M..  In May this year, she received a loan from SELFINA to establish a business selling clothes, purses and perfume.  She has successfully repaid this loan and now requires another to purchase additional stock and continue building her business.  Yusta is a single mother of three - Hassea, aged 18, Faustina, aged 15, and Haluni, aged 12.  She thanks you for your support.

loans.name: Semeni

texts.en:
It is said that Coca-Cola® is one of the most recognized symbols or brands in the world. And it’s true. Even in the most remote villages in Africa, there is usually some kind of bar selling Coke, Fanta, and Guinness. The hot weather makes these drinks all the more appealing - a very cheap marketing tool!

Semeni Daudi is one of many drink-sellers in Dar es Salaam, and the business generates a profit of about $80 a month. She requires a loan of $275 to purchase additional stock in bulk. Semeni is married to her husband, Emmanuel, with whom she has three children - July, aged 14, and twins Janet and Jakilini, aged 10.

SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of soda in bulk.

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en:
Eugenia B. brings a touch of the Congo to Tanzania.  In 2006, she established a business selling dresses made in the styles traditional to the former Zaire (now the Democratic Republic of Congo).  Eugenia is from the Muha tribe, which comes from the Kigoma region in the far west of Tanzania, on the border of Congo.  It is this connection with Congo and its influence on her homeland that inspired and enabled Eugenia to establish her business here in Dar es Salaam.  Also, the many refugees from the DRC who live here due to the civil war in their homeland are happy to have found a neighbour selling their traditional dress.

Eugenia has already repaid one loan from SELFINA and now requires another of $400 to purchase additional stock.  She is a single mother of two - Noela, aged 15, and Baby, aged 9.

loans.name: Santina

texts.en:
This is 31 year-old Santina H..  She runs a business selling cosmetics in Ukonga - a busy suburb of Dar es Salaam.  She requires a loan of $275 to purchase additional stocks of lipstick, eyeshadow, perfume and other luxuries for ladies.  Santina has three children with her partner, David.

loans.name: Ocosinguensas 1 Group

texts.es:
Luvia Marisol has a small restaurant in her home, where she serves regional cuisine for breakfast and lunch. She is 38-year-old widow with one son. With this business, she is able to cover the household expenses. The other members of the group have other occupations: Lizbeth Guadalupe (casual restaurant), Lilia Caritina and Catalina (cosmetics and perfume sales), Julia (mini market), Francisca Rosario and Viviana Elizabeth (sale of pork).

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

LUVIA MARISOL TIENE INSTALADO EN SU CASA UNA COCINA ECONOMICA EN DONDE ATIENDE A PERSONAS QUE DESEAN DESAYUNAR O COMER OFRECIENDOLES UNA VARIEDAD DE COMIDA TIPICA DE LA REGION. ELLA TIENE 38 AÑOS, UN HIJO, ES VIUDA Y CON EL NEGOCIO SE AYUDA CON LOS GASTOS FAMILIARES. LAS DEMAS INTEGRANTES DEL EQUIPO DESEMPEÑAN DIFERENTES ACTIVIDADES TALES: LIZBETH GUADALUPE (COCINA ECONOMICA), LILIA CARITINA Y CATALINA (VENTA DE PERFUMES Y COSMETICOS), JULIA (TIENDA DE ABARROTES), FRANCISCA ROSARIO Y VIVIANA ELIZABETH (VENTA DE CARNE DE PUERCO).

loans.use: Invest in kitchen essentials

loans.name: Ocosinfuenzas 2 Group

texts.es:
Maria del Carmen is a 34-year-old mother of two. She and her husband own an automotive repair and auto part shop. Their daughter, Tania Aracely, will also invest in the family business, since it is their sole source of income. The other members of the group have the following occupations: Antonia de Jesus (greengrocer), Claudia Guadalupe (manufactures balconies), Susana (greengrocer), Maria Concepcion (sells regional food), and Maria Ofelia (sells regional food).

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

MARIA DEL CARMEN TIENE 34 AÑOS, DOS HIJOS, JUNTO CON SU ESPOSO TIENEN UN TALLER MECANICO Y LAS REFACCIONES QUE NECESITE EL AUTOMOVIL AHI LOS VENDEN. SU HIJA TANIA ARACELY TAMBIEN INVERTIRA EN EL TALLER MECANICO Y EN LA VENTA DE REFACCIONES YA QUE ES LA FUENTE DEL INGRESO FAMILIAR. LAS DEMAS INTEGRANTES DEL GRUPO: ANTONIA DE JESUS (VENTA DE FRUTAS Y VERDURAS), CLAUDIA GUADALUPE (BALCONERIA), SUSANA (VENTA DE FRUTAS Y VERDURAS), MARIA CONCEPCION (VENTA DE COMIDA TIPICA) Y MARIA OFELIA (VENTA DE COMIDA TIPICA).

loans.use: Purchase of auto parts

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Remodel her store

loans.name: Ocosinguenzas 3 Group

texts.es:
Fatima del Carmen is 25 years old, she lives with her two sons and her husband, who makes metal doors and windows for living. She has a grocery store at home with which she contributes to family expenses. The other partners are Esutolia (Sells sweets), Romana Elvira (Artisan- recycles bags of chips and makes women’s purses), Maria del Carmen (Sells perfumes and cosmetics), Magdalena (Sells made to order shoes), Angela del Carmen (Sells perfumes and cosmetics) and Emilia del Carmen (Grocery Store).

Translated from Spanish by Christian Jimenez, Kiva Volunteer.

FATIMA DEL CARMEN TIENE 25 AÑOS, DOS HIJOS, SU ESPOSO LABORA HACIENDO PUERTAS Y VENTANAS DE METAL. ELLA TIENE INSTALADO EN SU CASA UNA TIENDA DE ABARROTES CON LA CUAL CONTRIBUYE AL GASTO FAMILIAR. LAS DEMAS INTEGRANTES: EUSTOLIA (VENTA DE ANTOJITOS), ROMANA ELVIRA ( ARTESANA, RECICLA LAS BOLSAS DE SABRITAS Y HACE BOLSAS PARA DAMA), MARIA DEL CARMEN (VENTA DE PERFUMES Y COSMETICOS), MAGDALENA (VENTA DE ZAPATOS A PEDIDO), ANGELA DEL CARMEN (VENTA DE PERFUMES Y COSMETICOS) Y EMILIA DEL CARMEN (TIENDA DE ABARROTES).

loans.use: Purchase Basic Commodity Products for the Store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: For purchase of paper goods and beauty products.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Stock her store with various products.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise and improve her work space.

loans.name: San Jacinto 1 Group

texts.es: CLARA LUZ TIENE 55 AÑOS, TUVO 9 HIJOS, SU ESPOSO VENDE HIERBAS MEDICINALES QUE SON DE  CONSUMO  DE LOS INTEGRANTES DE SU COMUNIDAD ELLA TIENE INSTALADO EN SU CASA UNA TIENDA DE ABARROTES. LAS DEMAS INTEGRANTES TAMBIEN CUENTAN CON UNA TIENDA DE ABARROTES A  DIFERENCIA DE  AMALIA QUE VENDE CREMAS, PERFUMES Y COSMETICOS ENTRE LAS INTEGRANTES DE SU COMUNIDAD

loans.use: INVERTIR EN LA COMPRA DE DISTINTOS PRODUCTOS BASICOS PARA SURTIR LA TIENDA DE ABARROTES.

loans.name: San Jacinto 1 Group

texts.es:
Clara Luz is a 55-year-old mother of 9. Her husband sells herbs for a living, while she runs a mini market from her home. The other members also have a mini market, with the exception of Amalia, who sells lotion, perfume, and cosmetics.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

CLARA LUZ TIENE 55 AÑOS, TUVO 9 HIJOS, SU ESPOSO VENDE HIERBAS. ELLA TIENE INSTALADO EN SU CASA UNA TIENDA DE ABARROTES. LAS DEMAS INTEGRANTES TAMBIEN CUENTAN CON UNA TIENDA DE ABARROTES A EXCEPCION DE AMALIA QUE VENDE CREMAS, PERFUMES Y COSMETICOS.

loans.use: Purchase of goods needed to restock a mini market

loans.name: Angelita

texts.es:
Mrs. Angelita M. J. belongs to the communal bank San Martin de Porras and lives in the San Martin region of Mariscal Cáceres, Juanjui. Her business is located in the sixth block of the Libertad extension. She devotes herself to selling wood, boards, and planks. Thanks to her husband’s support and the communal bank, she has successfully increased her wood sales. She currently counts on a large number of orders because she is friendly and treats her customers well, attending to their needs. That’s why she has such a large clientele. With this loan for $425 that she will repay in four months, she will purchase raw timber that will be cut down so she can fulfill all her orders. Mrs. Angelita is 47 years old and lives with her husband and their son. They work everyday to prove that there are no limits to the goals they can achieve.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Angelita M. J. pertenece al banco comunal San Martín de Porras, vive en la región San Martín, provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, distrito de Juanjui. Su negocio está ubicado en prolongación Libertad cuadra 6. Se dedica a la venta de maderas, tablas y listones. Gracias al apoyo de su esposo y al banco comunal logró aumentar sus ventas de madera, actualmente cuenta con una gran cantidad de pedidos porque les da a sus clientes un buen trato y los atiende con amabilidad, es por ello que tiene gran clientela. Con el préstamo de S/.1200.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará madera en cuartones para ser aserradas y así poder cumplir con todos su pedidos. La señora Angelita tiene 47 años y vive con su esposo y su hijo. Trabajando diariamente muestran que para cumplir las metas no hay limites.

loans.use: Purchase wood

loans.name: Ana Isabel

texts.es:
Mrs. Ana Isabel is 30 years old and currently lives in the Lamas district of Lamas, San Martín. She is a single mother and has one seven-year-old son. Mrs. Ana used to devote herself to selling fruit-flavored lollipops to cover the economic needs of her household. Later she decided to get involved in selling groceries, but she didn’t have enough money to expand her business before she joined the “Ciudad de los Tres Pisos” communal bank. With her first loan for S./300.00, she was able to buy a wider variety of products to stock her grocery store. Later, with her earnings and other loans she received from her communal bank, she bought rice, sugar, milk, noodles, vegetables, crackers, etc, and now she owns a variety store in her own home. With this loan of $525 which she will pay in 6 months, she will buy dozens of different brands and flavors of soft drinks, rice, 50 kg bags of sugar, packets of noodles, oil, boxes of soap, stews of different flavors, and so on, to offer to her demanding clientele. Her dream is to one day open a wholesale grocery store.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Ana Isabel tiene 30 años de edad, actualmente vive en el distrito de Lamas, provincia de Lamas, departamento de San Martín, tiene un hijo de siete años, es madre soltera. La señora Ana se dedicaba a la venta de chupetes de fruta para poder cubrir las necesidades económicas que tiene en el hogar, después decidió incorporarse en el negocio de los abarrotes, pero el capital que tenia no era suficiente para incrementar su negocio antes de pertenecer al banco comunal “ciudad de los 3 pisos”. Con el primer préstamo de S/: 300.00, pudo comprar mayor cantidad de productos para surtir la venta de abarrotes y posteriormente con las ganancias y con los otros préstamos que recibe en su Banco Comunal compró arroz, azúcar, leche, fideos, verduras, galletas, etc. y ahora posee un negocio con variedad, dentro de su propia casa. Con el préstamo de S/. 1500.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará gaseosas en docenas en su diversas marcas y sabores, arroz, azúcar en sacos de 50 kilos, fideos en paquetes, aceite y jabones en cajas, menestras en diferentes variedades y sacos, etc. para ofertar a su exigente clientela. Sueña con abrir una tienda mayorista de abarrotes.

loans.use: Purchase of groceries - rice, sugar, noodles, soaps, stews, etc - for sale in her store

loans.name: Celmira

texts.es:
Celmira is 52 years old and lives in the district of Lamas in San Martin. She has a grown up son who no longer depends on her. She lives with her husband, and her mother, who is quite old now and depends on her daughter for financial support. Coming from a humble family without much money, Clemira attended school up until the 3rd grade of primary school only. Today she works selling fruits and vegetables, but before she became a part of the communal bank she did not have enough money to sufficiently stock her business. With the first loan she received she was able to purchase fruits and vegetables to sell. With her earnings and additional loans, she has built her business in the municipal market of Lamas and now offers more variety. With this loan, which she will repay in 6 months, she will buy a greater quantity of produce such as bananas, oranges, lemons, yuca, cilantro and onions in bulk, etc. Her dream is to be able to open a shop in her own home.

La señora Celmira tiene 52 años de edad, actualmente vive en el distrito de Lamas, provincia de Lamas, departamento de San Martín. Tiene un hijo mayor de edad que no depende de ella, vive con su esposo y su madre anciana la cual depende económicamente de ella. La señora Celmira estudió hasta el tercer grado de primaria, puesto que procede de una familia humilde. La señora Celmira se dedica a la venta de frutas y verduras, pero antes de pertenecer al banco comunal “ciudad de los 3 pisos” no contaba con el capital suficiente para surtir su negocio. Con el primer préstamo de S/: 300.00 que recibió de Manuela Ramos pudo comprar frutas y verduras, posteriormente con sus ganancias y con los otros préstamos que recibe en su Banco Comunal posee un negocio con variedad en el mercado municipal de Lamas. Con el préstamo de S/. 800.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará mayor cantidad de frutas y verduras como plátanos en racimos, naranjas, limón, yuca en sacos, culantro en atados, cebollas en kilos, etc. Sueña con abrir una tienda de abarrotes en su propia casa.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO PURCHASE PRODUCE IN GREATER QUANTITIES TO STOCK HER BUSINESS, GROW HER PROFITS AND ONE DAY BE ABLE TO OPEN A SHOP IN HER OWN HOUSE.

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.es:
Consuelo is 62 years old and lives in the district of Lamas, in San Martin. She has 6 children - 2 sons and 4 daughters, all of whom are grown up now and help support their mother financially. Before joining the communal bank "Cuidad de los Tres Pisos", Consuelo worked as a seamstress, but this business was not very profitable and she decided to sell grocery items. However, things didn't work out as she'd hoped and instead she began her business selling dried, salted fish. She realized this business was profitable, but she didn't have the money she needed to begin. With the first loan she received, she was able to stock her business and begin selling from the municipal market of Lamas. With the new loan, which she will repay in 6 months, she will purchase different types of dried, salted fish, which she purchases wholesale. Her dream is to one day open a general store in her own house.

La señora Consuelo tiene 62 años de edad, actualmente vive en el distrito de Lamas, provincia de Lamas, departamento de San Martín. Tiene seis hijos, dos varones y cuatro mujeres, todos ellos son mayores de edad, los cuales la apoyan económicamente. La señora Consuelo antes de pertenecer al Banco Comunal “Ciudad de los Tres Pisos” se dedicaba a la costura, pero esta actividad ya no era muy rentable y decidió dedicarse a la venta de abarrotes, sin embargo, no le fue como esperaba, entonces se inició en la venta de pescado seco salado, vio que este negocio era muy rentable, pero no contaba con el capital necesario para incrementar su stock, es así que con el primer préstamo recibido en su Banco Comunal pudo incrementar su negocio ubicado en el mercado municipal de Lamas. Con el préstamo de S/. 2,000.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará pescado seco salado como paiche, tilapia, maparate, bocachico, arahuana, lisa, etc., los cuales comprará al por mayor en sacos. Sueña con abrir una tienda de abarrotes en su propia casa.

Translated by Kiva volunteer, Emily Charnes

loans.use: TO PURCHASE DRIED, SALTED FISH WHOLESALE, GROW HER PROFITS AND SAVE ENOUGH TO ONE DAY OPEN A GENERAL STORE IN HER OWN HOME.

loans.name: Gina

texts.es:
Gina is part of the group called Mientras Tanto, Nueva Amistad (new friendship). She lives in the region of San Martin where she has a business selling grilled meats and snacks. Her children and her husband help her prepare these items in their home. With the loan she received from Manuela Ramos, she has been able to grow her business. She now has a covered space with tables and chairs to serve her clients, and her business is growing every day. With the new loan, which she will repay in 4 months, she will buy materials for the roof, utensils for preparing and serving her food, as well as soft drinks.

La señora Gina pertenece al Grupo Mientras Tanto “Nueva Amistad”, vive en la Región San Martín, provincia de San Martín, distrito de La Banda de Shilcayo, domiciliada en la Asociación de Vivienda Nueva Amistad Mz B Lote 1 donde también está ubicado su negocio de venta de salchipapas y asaditos . En su casa le apoyan los hijos y el esposo en la preparación de estos alimentos y con el apoyo del préstamo de Manuela Ramos ha podido incrementar su negocio, de tal forma que ahora cuenta con un espacio techado y mesas para atender a sus clientes que día a día van aumentando. Con el préstamo de S/. 500.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará calaminas para el techado, utensilios para el servicio y bebidas gaseosas. La señora Gina tiene 29 años de edad, vive con su esposo y sus dos hijos. Ella se siente alentada por el apoyo de su familia y agradecida del apoyo de Manuela Ramos y tiene fuerzas para seguir adelante ya que sus niños aún son pequeños y quiere trabajar para poder educarlos. Está segura que su negocio es una gran oportunidad para crecer y poder cumplir con todas sus metas.

loans.use: TO PURCHASE ITEMS SHE NEEDS TO CONTINUE TO GROW HER BUSINESS, INCLUDING UTENSILS FOR PREPARING FOOD AND SERVING HER CUSTOMERS.

location.town: La Banda de Shilcayo - San Martín

loans.name: Juana Margot

texts.es:
Juana is 35 years old. Currently, she lives in the Lamas district of the province of Lamas in San Martin. She has three children who are still minors.

Before becoming a member of the “Ciudad de los Tres Pisos” (City of Three Floors) Communal Bank, she used to sell beauty products. With the first loan of S/. 300.00, she was able to buy toys and some perfumes, with which she started a business in the house where she lived. Thanks to her earnings, and with the other loans she received from her Communal Bank, she now owns a business selling a variety of products.

With the loan of S/. 900.00, which she will repay in 6 months, she will purchase toys for boys and girls due to the upcoming holiday festivities. She will also buy perfumes and clothing for men, women and children, as well as a variety of home decorations to offer her demanding clientele. She dreams of opening a children’s clothing store.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Juana tiene 35 años de edad, actualmente vive en el distrito de Lamas, provincia de Lamas, departamento de San Martín. Tiene tres menores hijos. La señora Juana antes de pertenecer al banco comunal “ciudad de los 3 pisos” se dedicaba a la venta de productos de belleza. Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300.00, pudo comprar juguetes y algunos perfumes, con lo cual abrió un negocio en la casa donde vivía, posteriormente gracias a sus ganancias y con los otros préstamos que recibe en su Banco Comunal posee un negocio con variedad de productos. Con el préstamo de S/. 900.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará juguetes para niños y niñas con motivo de estas fiestas navideñas, también comprará perfumes y ropa para damas, caballeros y niños y variedad de adornos para el hogar para ofertar a su exigente clientela. Sueña con abrir una tienda de ropa para niños.

loans.use: Purchase toys, perfumes, clothing and home decorations.

loans.name: Anicia

texts.en:
Anicia D. A. G. from Tarapoto, San Martin, owns a juice bar that sells refreshing fruit drinks and popular sandwiches. Founded in September of 2005 with $1, her business has grown by leaps and bounds. She attributes her success to her hard work, location, and product. Anicia shares space with her husband's busy motorcycle mechanic shop. Hot and tired mototaxi chauffeurs stop by the shop throughout the day and regularly buy Anicia’s delicious drinks.

Anicia is 24 years old and has a supportive husband and 2 young children. She is fun, friendly, and loves her business. Family members encouraged her to start the business as they recognized the opportunity to bring in extra income and knew how much she would enjoy working from home. Anicia is happier than ever and excited to be able to provide a better life for her children.

Over time Anicia has learned how to run an efficient business. Anicia joined the Community Bank Mujeres Rumbo Al Desarrollo where she was encouraged to take advantage of loans offered to their members. She is requesting a $675 loan to increase inventory and buy utensils and plates. In the future, she plans on making her juice bar more attractive and comfortable.

loans.use: To buy utensils and plates.

loans.name: Lesly Charo

texts.es:
Mrs. Lesly is 29 years old and currently lives in the Lamas district of Lamas, San Martín. She has two seven-year-old children, and is a single mother. Mrs. Lesley devoted herself to her household work and to caring for her family, and once in a while she would help her mother-in-law prepare cecina, a dried, smoked meat product. They depended on her husband’s income until she decided to dedicate herself to creating cecina and chorizo, a spicy smoked sausage. Seeing the need for additional cash, she also decided to join the “Ciudad de los Tres Pisos” (City of Three Floors) communal bank.

With the first loan she received from Manuela Ramos for S./300.00, she was able to purchase hogs to expand her business. She makes the cecina using facilities in her home, while selling the finished product in the city market in Lamas. Later, with her earnings and with other loans received from the communal bank, she buys more pigs to continue growing her business. With this loan for $525, which she will repay in six months, she will purchase live pigs to be sacrificed, and with their meat, she will make cecina, chorizo, and other products to cover the demand of her customers. She dreams of running a restaurant that serves traditional dishes.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Lesly tiene 29 años de edad, actualmente vive en el distrito de Lamas, provincia de Lamas, departamento de San Martín. Tiene dos hijos de siete años, es madre soltera. La señora Lesly se dedicaba a las labores de su hogar y al cuidado de su familia y de vez en cuando apoyaba a su suegra en la elaboración de cecina, prácticamente dependía del dinero que ganaba su esposo, hasta que decidió dedicarse a la elaboración de cecina y chorizo, viendo la necesidad de capital también decidió ingresar al banco comunal “ciudad de los 3 pisos”.

Con el primer préstamo que recibió de Manuela Ramos de S/: 300.00 pudo comprar cerdos para incrementar su negocio. La elaboración de la cecina lo realiza en las instalaciones de su casa, mientras que el producto terminado es comercializado en el mercado municipal de lamas, posteriormente con sus ganancias y con los otros préstamos que recibe en su Banco Comunal adquiere más cerdos para seguir creciendo con su negocio. Con el préstamo de S/. 1,500.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará cerdos vivos para ser sacrificados y con la carne elaborar cecina y chorizo y otros derivados para cubrir la demanda de su clientela. Sueña con tener un restaurante de platos típicos.

loans.use: Purchase of pigs

loans.name: Maria Ascencia

texts.es:
Maria Ascencia belongs to the "Las Margaritas Mientras Tanto" interim loan group, she lives in San Martín region, in San Martín province, La Banda de Shilcayo district, her home is at Jr. San Martín Nº 218 - Asociación de Vivienda San Juan, where she also has her business. She sells groceries and drinks and also has a pay phone.

Her husband and children help her with the chores around the house and business, so she has the time to effectively run her business, and she is thankful for the support of the microloans from Manuela Ramos, which enable her to buy groceries in large quantity and better stock her business in order to satisfy her customers' needs.

With the loan of 1300.00 soles, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will buy 3 sacks of rice, three of sugar, three cases of noodles, 2 cases of milk, and she will also do improvements to her locale to be able to expand it. In addition, she knows how to sew and part of the loan will be to acquire a sewing machine which will allow her to make clothing to sell in the business.

Maria Ascencia is 41 years old, lives with her husband and two children. She is a woman with many qualities which will enable her business and her family to be successful. She is an example of a woman leader and she has the wish to see the women of her group be successful as she is in every aspect of their lives and she encourages them to take advantage of the opportunities available Manuela Ramos is providing.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Maria Ascencia pertenece al Grupo Mientras Tanto “Las Margaritas”, vive en la Región San Martín, provincia de San Martín, distrito de La Banda de Shilcayo, domiciliada en el Jr. San Martín Nº 218 - Asociación de Vivienda San Juan, donde también funciona su negocio. Ella se dedica a la venta de abarrotes y bebidas al por menor y también presta servicios con un teléfono monedero.

Su esposo e hijos la ayudan en las labores de la casa y el negocio, por lo que ella tiene espacio para administrar mejor su negocio, es por eso que agradece el apoyo con los microcréditos que brinda Manuela Ramos, los cuales le sirven para comprar abarrotes en mayor cantidad y surtir más su negocio para así lograr satisfacer las necesidades de sus clientes.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1,300.00, el cual pagará en 4 meses, comprará tres sacos de arroz, tres de azúcar, tres cajas de fideo, dos cajas de leche y también hará mejoramientos en su local para poder ampliarlo, además, ella sabe coser y destinará parte del préstamo para adquirir una máquina de coser que le permitirá confeccionar prendas para exhibirlo en su negocio.

La señora María Ascencia tiene 41 años, vive con su esposo y dos hijos. Es una mujer con muchas cualidades para sacar adelante su negocio y a su familia, es un ejemplo de mujer líder y tiene el deseo de ver a las mujeres de su grupo realizadas como ella en todo aspecto en sus vidas y les anima a seguir aprovechando la oportunidad que Manuela Ramos está brindando.

loans.use: Purchase groceries (rice, sugar, noodles, milk, etc.)

location.town: La Banda de Shilcayo - San Martín

loans.name: Mariquita

texts.es:
Mariquita lives in the region of San Martin, province and districs of Lamas, which belongs to Banco Comunal Mujeres del 2000. She makes and sells breads and sweets in her own bakery which is located in her own house. Her home is located in the lower section of Lamas city, via Marcos Mori.

With the expertise of her husband as breadmaker they decided to install their own bread machine over 20 years ago, getting started with a small capital and hand-shaping the breads that they baked. Slowly but surely they were able to get the people's approval and at the same time get loans necessary to purchase a "sobadora" (this is a machine that allows them to bake more breads on a daily basis). To this date, production has increased and they work on individual orders, especially during holidays such as Christmas, New Year's, religious holidays, and anniversary of the city.

With the loan requsted, which they plan on paying back within 6 months, they will buy pans to be able to shape their breads, flour, sugar in bags, confectioners flowers, lots of eggs, other ingredients such as sugar, lard boxed milk, and special items for special orders to fullfill the public and private sector.

Translated from Spanish by Maria Peterson, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Mariquita vive en la región de San Martín, provincia y distrito de Lamas, pertenece al Banco Comunal Mujeres del 2000. Se dedica a la elaboración y venta de panes y dulces en una propia panadería que se encuentra instalada en su propia casa ubicada en la parte baja de la ciudad de Lamas, pasaje Marcos Mori s/n. Contando con la experiencia de su esposo como panificador deciden instalar su propia panadería hace mas de 20 años, iniciándose con un pequeño capital y un pequeño horno elaborando los panes en forma manual. Poco a poco fueron ganando la preferencia del publicó y con el ingreso al banco comunal que le permite obtener prestamos y comprar una sobadora (máquina que les permite elaborar mayor cantidad de panes por día). A la fecha su producción ha aumentado y trabajan con pedidos sobre todo en fechas festivas como Navidad, año nuevo, fiestas religiosas y aniversario de la ciudad. Con el préstamo de S/. 2,500.00, el cual pagará en 6 meses, comprará los moldes para panteones en cientos, harina y azúcar en sacos, frutas confitadas y pasas en kilos, huevos al por mayor, otros ingredientes como mantequilla, manteca en kilos, leche en cajas y esencias especiales para cubrir los pedidos de instituciones publicas y privadas. Mariquita junto a su esposo e hijos, quienes también ayudan en el negocio, sueñan con una mezcladora y una cortadora de panes y convertir la actual sobadora manual en eléctrica y así salir adelante y alcanzar las metas proyectadas.

loans.use: Purchase of containers and consumables (flour, sugar, fruits, raisins, etc.)
